reviewText:
Making this review for those concerned by Angry Joe's misinformed remark that Dirty Bomb is pay-to-win: it is NOT.

1. Angry Joe's Argument #1: You need a get a high-end loadout card to do good.
Counterpoint: The cards you get aren't game breaking at all. They simply offer sidegrades to the default weapons. I've never lost a gunfight because the other person had a better card than my lead (lowest grade) Skyhammer card!

2. Angry Joe's Argument #2: To get the best cards, you need to spend $55.
Counterpoint: I'm just gonna quote TotalBiscuit's counterargument: You can buy any loadout [card] in the game for ingame credits no problem." Not to mention Angry Joe's friend who was present during the video told him not to spend the $55. It was entirely unnecessary. The game never pressures you to spend a dime. The only way I'd feel pressured to spend real money is if they put in a skin that gives the overly masculine Skyhammer a super cute pink ballerina outfit (please!).

reviewText:
Once upon a time, I got my FPS kicks primarily through Unreal Tournament and other arena FPS games.  Then Unreal stopped being a thing, and I switched to the Call of Dutys and Battlefields; never could get into the Counterstrikes.  And you know, I had fun and everything, but all those easy kills made me complacent.  Then Dirty Bomb comes along kicks my teeth in.  In the good way, of course.  A proper return to form, with longer time to kills and purist FPS mechanics.  You don’t know how much you miss something until it’s been taken away from you, and then one day, many years later, you get it back.  I didn’t know it, but I actually needed Dirty Bomb.

So, what is Dirty Bomb?  Dirty Bomb is Splash Damage’s latest team-based, run and gun shooter where small teams race to complete objectives.  Dirty Bomb offers old school gameplay with an emphasis on mastering mechanics like movement, speed and mechanical skill, placing a rare premium on tracking and headshots, skillsets no longer really required in today’s glut of instant kill FPS games.  These elements are then given a modern coat of paint, with real world analogs like M4 carbines in place of link rifles.

Matches occur on large, multi-tiered maps with multiple, sequential objectives.  Brink-esque, light parkour elements offer additional mobility options for clever players to get into tricky spots or eek out moment to moment advantages over their foes.  So far, so Splash Damage.  Dirty Bomb also borrows from Team Fortress 2, with distinct classes catering to various playstyles and roles, all complementing one another.  While execution mode takes many cues from Counterstrike, Dirty Bomb’s Brink-style game modes, objective and stopwatch, is where Dirty Bomb shines.

Players step into the shoes of mercenaries, pre-selected before a match, “customized” via a loadout card with up to three augments.  Mercenaries are divided into light, medium and heavy mercs with light mercs being faster but less durable than their heavier counterparts.  Additionally, each merc is assigned a speciality or role.  Medics heal and revive.  Support rifleman provide ammo and call in various forms of artillery.  Engineers complete objectives faster and often rely on sneaky alternatives to direct combat.  The usual suspects.

A quick note for those of you who have seen Angry Joe's criminally bad review."  While loadouts with three augments are more powerful than loadouts with fewer augments

reviewText:
Splash Damage takes a little bit of Wolf: ET and Brink and brings them into a new class based shooter.

If you enjoyed Brink despite it's flaws, you will enjoy Dirty Bomb since it largely improves on what Brink tried to achieve. A fast-paced shooter with a wide variety of classes makes the objective based game modes fun to play.

While it may not have the neat parkour of Brink or the double jumping Nazis of Wolf: ET it finds a balance between both to bring fast and fluid movement to the game.

I have enjoyed playing it during the closed beta before it was on Steam and I look forward to it opening up so the game will be more populated, but I am little leery about the future of the game due to it being published by Nexon.

If you want a fast and teamwork oriented shooter I would recommend this game.

reviewText:
I've decided to remove my old review for this game and rewrite it, since my last one was rather very “enthusiastic” .

Dirty Bomb is a team objective based online first-person shooter, developed by Splash Damage, known for titles like Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory, or Brink. It’s gameplay is in many ways similar to previously mentioned Enemy Territory. One team has to make their way through the map, while completing certain objectives to clear obstacles on their way to the final objective, while the other team tries their best to stop them from doing so. The game has many “mercs” to play, each serving a certain purpose in the team – Medics, Engineers, Recons, Ammo suppliers / Fire supporters, and Combat mercs.

One of Dirty Bomb’s main premises is  “No hand holding” – and it shows in gameplay. With the game’s rather old school mechanics, veteran FPS players should feel right at home, as in gunfights, the winner isn’t determinated by pure randomness. A good player, using his movement, aiming, game sense and knowledge can be victorious over others, even if he’s outmatched by the opponent's health pool, or weaponry.  Team play is also important, as while experienced lone wolfs can easily stomp a public match where everyone is running about randomly without any purpose, it becomes nearly impossible to do so versus opponents with good cooperation.

The game is Free-To-Play, but fear not, there’s no any Pay-To-Win involved. Indeed, there are micro transactions, but they are more of a “Pay-To-Skip” thing. A dedicated player can get every gameplay changing elements in the game unlocked just by putting some time into the game. It might be slightly off putting for new players, who would want to advance though the game quickly, and it might also make them  think that they are at a disadvantage because they don’t own some stuff other players do. This is, to a certain point, not true, since 2 really great mercs are available from the start (Many very high level players play them often – just because they are available from the start, doesn’t mean they are worse, and that applies to other mercs in many ways – just because it’s a more support oriented merc, doesn’t mean he can’t do well at combat. All mercs are powerful, and you aren’t really at an disadvantage because you don’t own some of them), and there’s a 3 merc rotation that changes every 2 weeks or so. There's also the Loadout Card system, which is basically a weapon set for your merc. The cards have many qualities, and while it might be slightly confusing for new players, in reality, there are only 3 qualities that matter - Lead, Iron, and Bronze. Lead and Iron cards are the most common, but Bronze aren't really hard to get. The cards give you a certain set of perks, which give you very slight bonuses, none of them being bonuses related to your primary or secondary weapons, or your merc stats in general, excluding one perk which is pretty much useless. Lead cards have only 1 perk, and Iron has 2, while Bronze holds the maximum 3. Qualities above Bronze (Silver, Gold, Cobalt and Special Edition) are purely COSMETIC and work exactly like a Bronze card. This is a very important fact, since I've seen some people spread a misconception that Cobalt/Gold cards are pay to win.

The game isn’t perfect, though. Splash Damage is a fairly small development team, and the development speed is quite slow. The game has monthly updates, and while they do carry many important bug fixes and minor changes that affect the game in a good way, they usually don’t have much content (resulting in a fairly small map pool). Also, Splash Damage prefers to take their time when it comes to balance changes – a few mercs are considered fairly underpowered, and while the devs said they have plans to rework/buff them, it might take some time.  The game is also in a Open Beta state, which means you might expect bugs, slight performance problems (mostly if you have bad PC specs or you want to go for 100+ fps), but the game is otherwise fully playable.

Some people might be also wondering if the game has a cheater problem, and if the game is dead. To both of these questions, the answer is No. The cheating problem was basically solved when the new anti cheat came out for the game, and I haven’t met any cheaters ever since. Many players might have been mistaken for cheaters by inexperienced players though, but it’s not uncommon to see people falsely accuse players of cheating in any FPS game. About the playerbase, it might not be the biggest, but you will always find a public server to play on, and you might even easily find a ranked match in about 5-10 minutes if you play the game in peak hours! (Sad information for our American friends though, since as far as I know, ranked in America is pretty much dead.)

Personally, I think the bad sides of the game can be easily overlooked, since the game is free, and you don’t need to spend a single penny on it. The game is extremely fun, and many fans of shooter games will probably enjoy it as much as I do. I really recommend trying it out, but watch out, since you might get your ♥♥♥ kicked the first time you play it. Don't get discouraged though! Practice makes perfect, and with some trial and error, you will gradually improve over time.

reviewText:
I like to see this game as a mix between TF2 objectives and CS:GO gameplay and Battlefield-esque weaponry, with a more futuristic approach to it, featuring all the best aspects of those games.
Maps are fun to play and cleverly thought out, but not too complex. Weapons work exactly as you want them and all mercenaries fit different playstyles.
The graphics are very nice, with all things you would want to see implemented.
All in all: This game has a lot of potential.

reviewText:
First things first, I can't write worth ♥♥♥♥. I felt like I had to do  a review for this one as I feel the backlash is undeserved. I like the game and I'd hate to see it fail because of people spreading false information about it.



tl:dr version:
Fast paced objective based game. Keep your legs moving and track heads if you want to win. Don't touch iron sights unless at extreme distances.



Now for the not so short version.

What is Dirty Bomb? It is fast paced, multi objective team based shooter that is often compared to CS:GO and TF2. That isn't true. It is Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory with a sprinkle of Brink on top of it. You may ask what is multi objective? Think of Battlefield's Rush mode. You have to defend point A from being destroyed, but if your enemy beats you there you're pushed back further into the map and now you have to defend site B from the same fate.

Characters have different movement speeds and amount of health. Going faster means you sacrifice durability but being fast allows you to get away from (or into) danger much more quickly. Everyone has the ability to jump from walls and combine multiple wall jumps together allowing for some great jumps that will take your opponents by surprise.
The most often heard complaint is how weak the weapons are. This is another point that is not true. AIM FOR THE HEAD, THIS ISN'T CALL OF DUTY WHERE EVERYTHING DIES WHEN YOU GAZE IN THEIR GENERAL DIRECTION. Guns shoot where you point them and have very little spread so you can go ham with full auto at most ranges. Map selection is lacking so I can understand if some get bored of this faster.




Performance:
This has to be touched early. It's runs quite badly. On the highest settings I was getting drops to 40s and was forced to drop the settings to the lowest to get playable fps.
My specs:
i5-3570k@stock (lmao stock clocks)
16GB RAM
GTX980
Game was installed on WD Black 7200rpm HDD.



Payment model:
It is free to play with League of Legends style of character unlocking. You have 2 free characters to start with, Aura and Skyhammer. Both of them are top tier characters. There are also three free mercs on two week rotation for you to try out which always includes one engineer. All characters are either 30k or 50k credits.

When you first enter the game you might think that this is pay to win as there are so many locked mercs. All mercs offer a different playstyle but none of them are Tolkien's eagles. If you're bad, then you're bad.  No merc can save you from it, only practice can. Lack of knowledge and skill isn't a valid reason to call the game pay2win.

After each game you get certain amount of credits which is 12 per minute. I feel this should be increased to prevent people who play less thinking about how you have to spend money in order to win.You also get credits from doing missions and daily missions. Daily bonuses are 500 for first win and 500 for first match of the day for each game mode. Missions refresh every three hours and give you 500, 750 or 1000 credits and you have three missions active at the same time. On average it should only take you about an hour to complete them.

Now I do agree with that the prices are too expensive for real money. 30k mercs are 7 euros and 50k are 10 euros and a single bronze loadout card is 3.5 euros. YOU GET 30K BONUS ON YOUR FIRST 5 LEVELS, DO NOT SPEND IT ON CRATES AND WASTE IT LIKE A DUMBASS AS YOU'RE NOT GETTING THAT KIND OF MONEY AGAIN. NEVER SPEND CREDITS ON CRATES, IT IS WASTE.

You also have the option to buy elite crates and credit boosters. Boosters double your match credits (12 per minute to 24 per minute) but disappointingly it doesn't affect missions. If you ever want to use boosters buy them during double cred weekends. Elite cases give you either silver, gold or cobalt card.. Do not purchase elite cases or boosters unless you're willing to throw your money away to support the game, they're simply not worth it.



Loadout cards:
Each character has 9 cards with three cards for each primary with varying secondaries and perks. For example, 3 cards for rifle A, 3 cards for rifle B and 3 cards for rifle C . They are how you choose what you take with you into the match. The are multiple different levels of cards. Default, lead, iron, bronze, silver, gold and cobalt. Default has none, lead has 1 perk, iron 2 and bronze 3. Anything beyond bronze is pure bling. This may sound like obvious advantage over others who don't have as high level cards as others but that isn't the case. Guns > perks. The perks only help enhance what there already is, they're not like stopping power" from Call of Duty. They're only minor increases but not necessary at all for succeeding. Everyone else but medics and one assault class are totally fine with default cards.
The cards can be found from cases you get from playing
date:
buying elite cases (don't do it) or you can get the card of your choice from the store for either real money or 17.5k credits.

reviewText: Dirty Bomb is like a grittier, edgier version of the classic Team Fortress 2. Pitting 8v8/5v5 attacking teams and a defending teams against eachother in large sprawled out maps set in London. The attacking team has to attack (duh) a series of objectives to win, the defending team has to stop those guys, simple enough right? While in battle you can choose between 3 characters you own to switch between at any time, so say being a sniper isnt working out, switch over to medic and help your team in a pinch. In addition to that, each character has two unique special abilities (Like yknow, League of legends) you can also use in a pinch. For example one character can throw an airstrike beacon that shreds everything within range if they dont GET OUT OF THERE and he can also give ammo packs to his teammates, get it now? Every character is like that, and it's pretty cool. There arent exactly a ton of maps just yet, but the ones the game already offers are pretty fun, they gotta be just big enough to contain all those players and objectives, just not TOO big. Anyway the last thing i'd comment on is the loadout" system. Which essentially replaces character customization for different loadouts in the form of trading cards. Each character has a variety of different loadouts you can buy which contain different weapons/gadgets for the character depending on the card you have. It's an interesting idea
date: but also kind of confusing.\n\n... Or TL;DR in a nutshell

reviewText:
The game has potential, yes.
It's there! A few tweaks here and there, a few modifications, and you got yourself a hot pile of awesome for dinner!

But there's one glaring issue.

Nexon has a hand in it.

Nexon... how do I put this.
Think of it like this.
Imagine a Cash Shop as a person.
He's nice, he'll give you those awesome rocket pops for a dollar that you love. You know, the ones with the bubble gum ball in the middle. Great stuff!
Now take that, then slap Nexon on his nametag.
He will then ruin your hair, slam you against a wall instead, and tell you to fix that hair he'll give you a hat. It's a moderatly priced hat, but in 30 days he'll come back and take that hat back and you'll have to buy another one.
Unless you dish out three to four times the normal amount... then you can keep that hat!
Course next week there will be even MORE hats to choose from.
Or he'll show you a gun. Now this gun is the same gun you can get in game. But this gun does more damage. And the only way to get that gun with more damage, is to buy this version of it.

In a nutshell.
The game has a Cash Shop.
Nexon is involved.

That cash shop is going to get bad. Very, very bad.

So if you want to play the game. Play it NOW. Play it RIGHT NOW! Play it till you're sick of it. Play it till you dream of the day you can play that tile placing game carcassonne just to not be playing this game anymore. Play it till you're considered addicted, and then claim you're not addicted but relize you're rivaling Skyrim in hours played!!!

Because eventually... down the game's road... it's lifespan... there will be that time when the game dips" in popularity. And when it does.... Nexon will be there.
With arms filled with items you can buy to

reviewText:
I would like to start this review with a disclaimer. This is one of the best shooters I've played in a VERY long time. I couldn't name for you the last time I had this much fun with a shooter. The gun-play is crisp and responsive, the level design is beautiful and intelligent and the refreshing return of objective based and team-play oriented combat gives every action you perform and kill you execute out feel meaningful to the overall outcome of the game. However...

I cannot recommend this game in it's current form. This is almost entirely due to the business model of the game, for those unaware of it who don't want a long winded explanation I shall attempt to keep it brief. So you have 2 main aspects to the game's business model, cards/crates and mercs. The mercs are on a weekly rotation of 3 and week as of writing this review (this is already too little to have on rotation). The mercs all have differing play styles and unique personality however I believe that individual mercs are FAR too expensive. they can to anywhere from $10 to $15 at one point which is almost as much as you would have paid to get into the closed beta testing! The other aspect being the cards/cases is also rather unfair. Each case contains a guaranteed card and costs 1,000 in-game cash. This is already pretty expensive. The credits are quite hard to earn and the cases will almost never yield a worthwhile card. Something is to be said for the unavailability of credits as a real-money purchase (as of writing this review) but I would bet my bottom dollar that this is only temporary. It is also extremely expensive to trade up merc cards both in lower tier cards and in credits, making it an in-viable option by certain points in the game.

Now I love Splash Damage and I believe they are an extremely tallented developer who put their hearts into projects. I loved Enemy Territory to bits, I thought Brink was an extremely underrated game and I found the Batman: Arkham Origins multiplier rather enjoyable (if a bit rushed) however consumers can not excuse a game of unfair business models with the defense of its game-play. The saddest thing about this is that I do not believe this is entirely Splash Damage's fault. Instead I point a hesitant finger at Nexon, the publishers of the title. Do not forget, readers, that they might have a larger hand in this issue than you might think.

So in summary? Fix your business model, then we'll talk.
voteText: 534 of 788 people (68%) found this review helpful 39 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Back in 2003, Splash Damage released a standalone freeware game known as Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory.  It combined the speed and movement of Quake and the hitscan and aiming mechanics of Counter-Strike into a objective-based game.  The focus on team-oriented objectives created a very popular fps game that sadly had a community die off and move on.

Splash Damage attempted to revive the series with with Enemy Territory: Quake Wars, but was largely unsucessful.

Welcome to Dirty Bomb, the newest reincarnation of the gameplay.  It feels and plays like the first legitemate sucessor to Enemy Territory.  With similar team-based classes, and a much more noob-friendly interface than ET could ever muster, this game could possibly be the first game that is a legitemate competitor to CSGO in terms of competitive FPS games... as long as Nexon doesn't ♥♥♥♥ everything up and make the game p2w.

The shooting mechanics combine that of quake and counter-strike.  Players are tanky and can take 2 or 3 headshots to kill.  However, similar to CS, aiming for the head is highly rewarding as most guns will kill in 8 to 10 shots (generally it takes a little less than 2 seconds to kill a player with body shots).  Additionally, you're highly accurate while moving, which makes strafe shooting a viable and effective strategy.

Don't let the cartoonish atmosphere fool you, however.  Despite its simplistic nature, there is a lot of depth to the game in taking fights, healing with medics, and even intentionally suiciding to respawn with full ammo or to defend an objective.

If you like playing competitive FPS games, give this one a fair shot.  The gameplay is quite unforgiving for new players, but highly rewarding if you stick with it.

reviewText:
Game is interesting, fast paced with a mix of quake arena and team fortress 2.

Maps are large and contain multiple objectives. Classes are varied though not very balanced, expected since it's a beta.

Business model isn't terrible, not pay-2-win as most claim but the boosts and classes are overpriced. You have to grind quite a long time to unlock classes in the F2P currency.

Overall, not a bad game and can be quite fun. Without a doubt worth the download as it's quite playable without spending any cash.


Why would I not recommend this game then? Hackers. Script kiddies. Scum of online gaming communites.

This game is infested with hackers, they're in every other offical ranked matchmaker game and in most custom servers. The game is literally unplayable, reporting and trying to kick them does nothing, and if you leave your unplayable ranked match you get to look forward to a 24 hour ban while the script kiddie doesn't get punished.

There are hackers that are level 30+ and have been ruining games since early beta, but they're still allowed to ruin games without punishment. Meanwhile, legitimate peoples get punished if they try to leave these games.

Until these scum are removed and the cheat detection software improved, don't waste your time or money with this game.

Uninstalling the game myself. Will check the updates now and then to see if they do anything about this infestion, but would not recommend this game to anyone in it's current state.

reviewText:
Very hard to really sum up how I feel about this game. On one hand, the graphics are appealing to the eye, and yet arent super high end. The sound work is fine, and the gun play is what you would expect from the makers of enemy territory and brink. So what about the gameplay?

There are a few areas where the game is a lot of fun. Mostly as I mentioned already, the gun play. Shooting, jumping, dodging, stabbing... it all flows very smooth and is very fast paced. I enjoy not having to ALWAYS use iron sights to shoot, allowing quicker from the hip shooting. The objective based maps are great too. I like how you arent always on the same part of the map, as they require you to move through the map as the teams do the objectives.

So would I recommend this game? Sadly, no. Not right now. There are some pretty big issues, none of which are bug or programming related, that keep this game from being really fun and replayable for me.

(take note, NONE of these issues have anything to do with the games real money payment system. I havent spent a dime on the game, and I dont feel like its hindered me in any way short of not having access to all the classes)

reviewText:
Currently one of my (and my friend's) favorite team based FPS shooter!
It's fast paced, fun, visually appealing and has great map design and mechanics.

The idea is to build up your own mercenary squad from (currently) 16 different mercs. You battle from 5vs5 to 8vs8 games on various maps and gamemodes. You can always bring three of your favorite mercs in game - and change the active merc during respawn.


LoadoutsYou can customize these mercs with different type of loadout cards that determine your weapon loadouts and character bonuses.

For example, one loadout card might change your primary weapon from SMG into shotgun and add/remove some augments (No fall damage, reload weapon while sprinting etc.) or new skills (quickly toss enemy's grenade back) to your character.

There's 6 levels of loadout cards from Lead to Cobalt and they all have different skins and augments that have an impact to your character behavior and skills. Starter loadout cards have only different weapons, while the best loadout cards can include 3 augments too. There's roughly 10(?) different type of loadout cards per level for a character. This might sound complex at first, but it's a really nice, simple system.

You get new loadout cards as rewards from matches and once you have enough unlocked, you can get rid off the 'poor' ones by crafting them into better, higher level cards.

The great thing here is that a skilled player with a stock loadout card can still easily kill a group of flashy mercs with the best" loadouts and nothing makes you superior compared to other players. Only skills and group tactics matter.

The MercsThe mercs have different roles. They are categorized in healing
date: support and assault units. As I'm writing this there's currently 16 different mercs to choose from. There's few free mercs to try out every month and you can easily use these to get comfortable with the game and see what kind of play style fits you perfectly.\n\nEveryone's personal squad is built from snipers

reviewText:
Product received for free

Dirty Bomb is the best FPS on steam that no one is playing!

Dirty Bomb has a FREE TO PLAY, yet VERY FAIR business model. Characters are $10 each, however can be purchased through in game credits just with a few days of play. Characters are constantly on free rotation, and there's a considerable variance in the way each hero plays and feels. Dirty Bomb offers a simple yet difficult to master parkour system which allows for some inventive and challenging ways to flank the enemy. The game is very hospitable towards new players, and is easy understand and play, yet it offers enough depth, and a steep learning curve which will challenge even the most seasoned of FPS players.

I've played for over 100 hours, and I haven't felt the need to spend a single dollar on this game. Dirty Bomb has plenty of dedicated servers, some of which are level capped to cater towards less or more experienced players. There's no excuse not to give this game a chance. Although it may appear generic, the gameplay and presentation are very polished, and offers the best FPS experience I've had in years. It's entirely free, so why not give it a chance?

9.5/10

reviewText:
TL;DR Dirty Bomb is a great title: it offers highly competitive and balanced gameplay, thanks to an emphasis on objectives and teamwork. Built around specialized characters and a unique card loadout system, it offers an enjoyable team experience. However, the in-game currency reward system is severely lacking.

Warning: If you play first-person shooters enitrely for team deathmatch or to go for kills, you will likely not enjoy this game; all game modes and most incentives are objective-oriented, and the intentional absence of a team deathmatch mode makes that point clear.

ProsFast-paced gameplay
Graphics are modern and unique
Various specialized characters w/ unique abilities
Maps are well-designed & balanced
Objective-oriented game modes
Dedicated servers
Free-to-play without pay-to-winConsCompetitive mode matchmaking isn't balanced yet
Limited map selection (only five)
In-game currency reward rates are frustratingly too slow
Occasional minor rendering issues
Can't create a party w/ friends to join a server together
I've played the game since the first closed beta came out, and it's only gotten better since. It's fast-paced without simply becoming a visceral blur like many titles become, and offers highly competitive gameplay in a friendly environment. Playing with friends is very enjoyable thanks to multiple complimentary roles and loadouts, even though joining a server than can accomodate 2+ without filling up before they can join is sometimes a challenge. Everything about the objective-oriented gameplay satisfies my competitive thirst, but the game's currency reward system (CR) is TERRIBLE, just as others have mentioned. I purchased the Ultimate Starter Pack as well as an 18-hour credit booster, and it's still mediocre. I can be the MVP, get a higher score than the entire enemy team combined, and still get a meager 1000CR (AFTER the boost) for 20 minutes of play; with individual characters costing 50,000CR and individual loadouts costing around 17,000CR each, you'd have to spend hundreds of hours (or hundreds of dollars) to get all the characters and just decent cards. The missions given simply aren't enough, and even the buyable credit boosts don't help nearly enough to justify their cost. In the end, the game is wonderful and fun and oh-so-addicting yet sadly doesn't excel to a more prominent position in the larger gaming community due to a lackluster and unsatisfying reward system too heavily bent on forcing you to spend real money to get new content.

reviewText:
First off if you are worried about the game being P2W. Check this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f8Z8985-FMM

Ok so first off the game is fun. It has solid gameplay it is competitive, and most importantly it is stable.

The game is different from other first-person games flooding the market at the moment in that it rewards good tracking over twitch reactions. It goes back to the old days where hip-firing your weapons was the way to go, there is ADS but unless you are a sniper it isn't really used.

The game is also extremely objective based, if you don't work with your team you will lose. Learn your role and play it, everyone depends on everyone else you aren't a lone wolf.

That being said if you are ready for a steep learning curve and want to get into a competitive game that require you to practice, this is the game for you.

Installs 'anticheat' xigncode as administrative system service that phones home directly via unencrypted HTTP requests to IP address (no DNS request) when game is run. That means your data is transmitted to a third party unencrypted. Not cool.

Doesn't instill confidence or professionalism when their anticheat website 'Wellbia.com' is published with a generic unhardened Drupal CMS.

Below is the list of software I have attempted to run with this 'anticheat'.
If you run ANY of the following, your game will not run.

McAfee Enterprise Antivirus
Fraps (possibly fixed)
DXTory
Process Explorer
Process Hacker
Sandboxie
Net Limiter

Be advised that quitting/killing the application will not work if it has loaded dll's and/or drivers at startup.

Being that I run 6 of the applications above, I would need to significantly modify my entire system just to get this game to run. I find this completely unacceptable and strongly advise against this game because of this.

You have been warned.

reviewText:
Someone set up us the bomb. -Mechanic, Zero WingI would like to give a special thanks to my friend, X Phantom, for proof-reading this review before beginning. Dirty Bomb is a class-driven first-person shooter developed by Splash Damage centered around player-versus-player skirmishes. There are multiple game modes to compete in, as well as various stages to strategize and characters to either unlock or purchase. As a disclaimer towards this game and review, I do not purchase downloadable content packages for free-to-play titles because I believe that such games require enough composition to deter from said acquisitions. I also must say that, though it does take time, nearly everything this title has to offer can be unlocked without using its transaction-based in-game currency.
Here are just a few reasons to give Dirty Bomb a go (other than it being free, of course):

Gameplay - Dirty Bomb holds a very interesting strategic aspect unlike many first person shooters: five varying ability styles consisting of Fire Support, Medic, Engineer, Assault, and Recon actions. This title holds similar characteristics to MOBAs in the sense that each featured character has their own unique statistics block and special abilities, with improved features depending on the rarity of the selected loadout. For instance, Proxy is generally a close-ranged shotgunner with proximity mines, a quickened interaction speed with given objectives, and an enhanced walking and sprinting speed; Skyhammer, on the other hand, throws ammunition packs which can be used by both the dispensing player and their teammates, and an air strike attack that can be used after each cooldown period. The controls in this title are similar to those of other first person shooters, with the addition of the Q key acting as the Ability button.

Game Modes - In the debut game mode, Execution, one side must plant and retain a bomb at one of several points of interest while the second team either prevents this occurrence or disarms the bomb; picture, if you will, the Counter-Strike game series while deliberating on this concept. This game mode consists of ten rounds, each lasting a maximum of three minutes. The attackers and defenders swap sides after the midpoint of six rounds in each game, and the winners are decided when one team accumulates the majority of wins within ten rounds or by earning seven victories before the opponents.
///  Objective Mode is relatable to Execution Mode in that the teams are split between attackers and defenders, but holds its own uniqueness, entailing completing multiple tasks within the given time of fifteen minutes. This mode requires a great amount of coordination with teammates, as every moment could alter the course of each game. This mode can be quite hectic yet enjoyable with the sequenced events.
///  Stopwatch Mode is unlocked after a given player level, and is comparative to Objective Mode in that the two teams are separated into attackers and defenders, swapping roles after fifteen minutes or the completion of the primary objective; this signifies that each game concludes after thirty minutes. If both teams reach the same amount of objectives within the given time of thirty minutes, the game goes into overtime mode to decide the victorious team. I find this mode to be very amusing, even with my own dislike for time-based competition.

TL:DR - I must admit that I had not experienced the same hacker problem as many of the other individuals that reviewed this game, though I will not omit that the problem may, indeed, exist in the community. Dirty Bomb’s community-as I have experienced-and relatable content is enough to entice the player to return to the arena. I recommend this title to those interested in class-drive first person shooters and skirmish-oriented matches. Thanks for reading.

Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews.

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb... No... It's AIR STRIKES THE GAME!

In all seriousness, the game is pretty solid. While some may say things are unbalanced or there is issues with abilites (I'm looking at you Air Strikes) the game overall is fun even with it. Why? Because you can't use Air Strikes all day every day. It's better to set them up while enemies are under heavy fire.

Take the Case system from CS:GO or Mass Effect 3 MP but have them give cards instead of guns.
Take Quest reward system from Hearthstone or Heroes of the Storm.
Take the hero roster setup, unique abilites and hexagonal look from Heroes of the Storm.
Take the Combat from Team Fortress 2 and build on it.
Then toss them all into a filthy melting pot.

What do you have? You have a dirty, dirty bomb.

7/10 Would Air Strike again.

reviewText:
So after 360 odd hours on this game I'm ready to give my honest opinion on it. I'll provide a short and an extended version.

Short:

Pros:
-True free to play model, i.e. no pay to win
-Decent in-game progression rate (250h on average to unlock every single mercenary with in-game currency)
-Many different mercs with very different abilities
-Team based: medic, recon, engineer, assault, fire support (ammo provider)
-Nice skins for your mercs

Cons:
-Bugs, bugs and more bugs. Old ones stay, new content brings more of them.
-Can't maintain constant fps even on medium settings on my rig (GTX 980 4GB, i7 3.6GHz, 16GB ram, 1Tb HDD)
-All matchmaking/balancing tools are horrible. (I'll go into detail as to why in the extended section)
-Poor content: 6 maps for one game mode, second mode being one half of the first one. 2 maps for the third mode.
-Server issues: connection lost, lag spikes, teleports, frequent deaths behind the wall (even with only 24ping)
-High knowledge required from new players for an effective game
-Spit in the face attitude towards the long standing community

extended version:

The game has a big variety of mercenaries, but only two are available at start. There are ammo providers with area denial abilities and the pure assault mercenaries, with either grenades or miniguns. There are health point variations between mercs making 1vs1 interesting. There are also a few snipers with no sway on their weapons (you do with this information what you want). Some neat medics with different health providing abilities and finally the engineers with tools to defend a certain point, planting, repairing and defusing faster than others.

The in-game credits can be gained pretty fast, given one plays regularly and does the different proposed missions each 3 hours. And unfortunately everything gets unlocked in under 300h. You have then still the loadout system to spend credits in. Basically, each merc has a set of 9 loadout cards which represents a unique combination of primary, secondary and melee weapon. A combination of three variants of each specific for each merc but sharing some weapons with others. Loadout come with different rarity levels. The bronze level is the base level with three augments or perks attached to each loadout. Rarer loadouts have exactly the same equipment and perks, but with a different skin. Lower than bronze loadouts, lose one perk at each level, making them worse. You start with a clean basic loadout and have to get better loadouts to reach at least bronze and be at the same level as everyone else. You can either get a case drop at the end of games, or pay 1000 in-game credits for one case.

The case system is based on randomness and you may get one random loadout of random rarity for a random merc (even one you do not have access to). You can pay for elite cases with real money this time. Elite cases contain silver as the lowest rarity you can get (it is one level of rarity above bronze). It's a money pit for people wanting a specific loadout in a specific color and rarity, but it doesn't affect the game in a pay 2 win fashion whatsoever so I don't mind.

Unfortunately what affects the game alot is the numerous bugs that keep getting introduced and bug smashing seems to not be the developpers strength. They've even once removed a type of missions since they couldn't fix what was wrong with it. Althought their official statement was the removal due to the community's request. Ehem.. sure. Bugs are plentyful and come in many colors: dissapearing abilities, throwables that don't get thrown or get thrown twice, reviving that actually kills your ally, hit detection on certain deployable models is bad, getting kicked from the game by the anti-cheat because the anti-cheat engine isn't stable and keeps crashing, etc. The list is so long by now and they keep adding more bugs at each update. There is alot of frustration involved in running into theses bugs repeatedly. Especially the horrible looping sound bugs that have been around since closed beta.

The new and recent execution mode has also brought tons of bugs with it. Overall the mode containing two maps are not enough and the copying of the counter strike mode is a failure due to the game being set in an invariable 7vs7 setting and the ability to revive people. There is little strategy involved other than moving in a pack of 7...

Finally the biggest issue of this game is the balancing/matchmaking. The competitive mode has a tendency to match you with strangers when you're playing alone and then makes you five strangers face a full pre-made team of 5 players. There's no fair matchmaking there I guarantee you. On top of that, balancing feels like its made by mokeys banging rocks together. The public matches are just the same. One game in 50 ends up being magically balanced. There is no real logic as to how players are matched with each other although the devs assure there's a hidden system. Unfortunately when you see people who are not even level 7 on one team paired up against people in the high 20's 30's it just doesn't make sense.

There is a vote shuffle function but as the system doesn't include non voters as a vote for the majority, people not wanting to vote or not noticing the vote being passed are not taken into account. This leads to many votes failing to pass, especially when a few players of the community vote no" as for once they're in the overpowered team. Repeated stomping due to imbalanced games will do that to you.

On a final note
recommended: nor forcing you to do the tutorial and many people skip it as they think it's just another shooter game. Countless times have I needed to tell people that you can revive downed allies as a medic or that as one specific merc you can provide ammo to yourself and others. There is no telling how much damage the newcomers  do to the health of a game. They lack all knowledge and there is nothing forcing them to stay in their max level 5 servers. Worse! The new way the quick join functionality works is that it only allows newcomers to play execution mode where there are no level limitations

reviewText:
DECENT GAME: Here's why!

Pros:
+ Fast paced
+ OBJECTIVE BASED - Doesn't matter how many kids you kill little Bobby, but if you can't get the damn objective, you will LOSE every time.
+ Lots of different classes to choose from
+ Nice level design. I'm a sucker for any urban maps, and thank goodness there's  a lot of them.
+ Side objectives in the match which switches up tactics REAL quick.
+ Case drops are so often (well for me) you'll get your 3 perk loadout in no time without spending your pocket change. You'll only use about 1,500 credits, which in the end is only 2 challenges.
+ Challenges promote different game types to be played, which in the end thrive people to play not just Stopwatch, or Objective.
EDIT: + Did you like Battlefield 3? Did you love Rush, and more importantly Operation Metro? Look no further, I get a major battlefield vibe from this game, and the map 'Underground' reminds me of the old Operation Metro.

Cons:
- GRIND FEST - It's gonna take you A LOT of time for you to get that class you really want, or to get that 'rare' loadout color. Some classes cost 50,000 credits. Yes 50k. That's either 20+ hours of playing (given you're completing every challenge in the 3 hour rotation period, as well as starting out at 0 credits.) or buying to get the classes. I'd DEFINITELY recommend finding one class you love, buy it ASAP, and be happy with what you have!
- Abilities are WAY TOO QUICK on cooldown. Do you like orbital strikes, or carpet bombs? Look no further you'll get spammed 24/7 with these abilities.
- Cases = CS:GO cases. No no no, not just a gun skin, but everything in your loadout. No selection if you just want to get a card for Kira, or SawBonez, all by chance. No selction in skin you would like, perks, or the weapon type itself.
- Medics overpowered. Yea let me jump off the walls up to 2 times with my perk so you can't shot me and blast you at point blank in the face with the shotgun. Hope you don't mind.
- Like gambling? Save yourself money and don't play this game. You'll only throw your stuff just like Cro_ from CS:GO
- No customization on your weapons. What if I don't want my sight on my gun? What if I want a red dot sight, or I want a blue camo, or maybe I want a silencer on my weapon!
EDIT: - The voice chat is very bad quality; as in it sounds like the $20 mics that kids have on Xbox back in like 2008. If the mic qaulity was better, as if it was comparable to what the voice chat quality on CS:GO, I'd have no such issue.

I did this review on June 8th 2015, just to let everyone know!

Overall: 6.5/10 - I'll play it, but I don't know if I'd put hundreds of hours into it.

reviewText:
I'll rewrite this review and simplify because apparently many people have trouble reading. So I'll make it simple and easy for them.

Pros-
- Game runs well.
- Game looks good. Very familiar feel for Brink players.
- Gameplay is Fast and fun
- Controls are tight and fluid.

Cons-
- Mercs just cost too much, considering what you get.
- Get ready to grind for ages for little reward if you F2P.
- Balance issues. (Especially proximity mines and shotguns)
- Loadout card system is awkward and rigid.
- No real customization.
- Hackers/Cheaters are becoming a problem.


Now don't get all bent out of shape and mad because I'm not recommending a game you like folks. The game has a lot of potential and it can and will be good once they fix some things, in particular do a bit of balancing.
I'd like to see more customization as well, as right now it's all dependant on the cards, literally.

My main argument against right now is just the balancing. I've seen too many rounds where as many people as possible switch to Aura just to use her shotgun. Also the proxy mines don't have an activation time, like they claim to. People are lobbing them as stealth" grenades and they blow up on impact.

My secondary reason against recommending the game is the absurdly high price of the game.
Let's do some math
date:
shall we?

You get on average between 100c-150c per game.
One single loadout card costs 1000c.
So therefore you'll be playing 7-10 matches roughly
recommended: to earn one single loadout card. (Unless you're lucky enough to get a crate drop.)\nThat could easily be a couple of hours of play or more.\nNow open that card up to see what you get. Surprise! You got a lead card

reviewText:
After 78 hours with this game. I can whole heartly recommend it.
Its a great and fun shooter with the mix of team fortress in art style to call of duty somewhat in gameplay yet it retains its
unique style as a game.

The game over time has become more balanced than it was when I first played the beta till now. Weapons are great, characters are fun to play with.

Yes. its widely known that not every game is for everyone, however if Dirty Bomb has every peaked your interest then I can say give it a try and you might like it or even fall in love playing the game.

Dirty Bomb gets a 9 out of 10 for being a original shooter and one that is fun to play. Kudos to Developer Splash Damage for a great and superb game.

reviewText:
This is a game to keep an eye on, even if you aren't ready yet to fork out the $20 for the early access into the beta. You have probably already read a bunch of information on the game, so I won't go into details on gameplay aspects, but rather reflect on some things that come with a bit of playtime. Overall, I have found the game is shaping up well in many respects and the core product itself is addicting and satisfying.

I think one of the important things to clarify is the loadout system and accusations of p2w elements. One thing that many people don't realise is that there is no gameplay impact/benefit for having silver and gold tier loadout cards over bronze. Bronze tier cards are fairly easily craftable and obviously are less rare when opening cases. I have bronze cards for all the classes I play and in some cases multiple. It does not take long to get hold of them, and even the benefits/perks they do give are in most cases trivial and not game-breaking anyway. Gold cards, for the moment, only grant a different skin. So in that sense, there isn't a huge advantage for people who have playtime on the game and have had time to acquire more loadout cards. As far as the competitive community goes, there are hopes that the loadout system might be revised in some way to promote more balanced and competitive play so that one team on a particular map isn't benefited in anyway because of a particular gun/perk on a loadout that the other team doesn't have access to, which I think only makes sense if the game has a desire to be a competitive FPS.

The other p2w accusation comes from the way mercs (classes) are acquired and introduced and also their relative strength to the other classes. As far as I know, in theory and in design no class should be better" than another. Confusion comes however when certain classes are in their current state not completely balanced and they are off rotation. This creates a scenario where a class that is strong in the current balance of the game (which is far from finalised) but that isn't accessible to a starting player is viewed as a p2w element of the game. Essentially though this is not by design
date: but rather by virtue of the nature of balancing computer games. So
recommended: in short this game is not a p2w title by design
hoursPlayed: but because of the ever evolving question of balance
voteText: these accusations are being tossed around probably to get the attention of developers.\n\nI do however want to set realistic expectations with regard to how quickly you can unlock classes. To unlock classes through grinding out in-game credits takes a rather absurd amount of time

votesFunny: I think $6 is fine
commentsCount: but $10 is really pushing it with regard to what most players would see as reasonable to ask. It would be a real shame if people were deterred from playing the game simply because unlocking new classes is just two inaccessible.\n\nPlease try this game for yourself and don't be put off by people who have had a negative experience with it after 30 minutes of game time. I have already spent > 100 hours on this game playing with friends who also enjoy it and don't regret it

reviewText:
This is a review of the Beta Build; since that is when I started playing.

First, it's a free to play game, so no matter what I spent absolutely no money to own this game or to play it, that is a plus no matter what.
Now to the good and bad about this game.
Let's do the bad first.
Bad:
It feels a lot like a CoD clone or at least the multiplayer.
The gameplay is somewhat repetitive.
Because of the characters all looking the same, at a quick glance it can be difficult to discern friend from foe in the heat of the moment.
You have to unlock (nearly) all the mercs, this is where the F2P really shines because like most they have options to spend real money, however, you can simply play the game and earn in-game credits to purchase Mercs with and not need to spend cash, this may be both a good and a bad thing.

Good:
The combat is smooth, fast paced and each character has special abilities, adding a new level of challenge with having to decide which character will be best for you and how best to use them.
The set-up is different from most games, requiring you to select three characters (or mercs) and using them to switch between during battle.
As stated above, there is an in-game credit system that rewards gameplay so that you can purchase Mercs and have no need to spend real money.

Overall this game is pretty fun. It isn't an A+ but I'd give it about B+, it is fun, easy to pick up and since it's free there really isn't much to lose.
If you enjoy FPS with a fast pace, then download this game.

Did I mention it's free?

And since people seem to need specification. I mean that it feels like playing the multiplayer of CoD; simple action, running & gunning with quick death, characters who look similar and mostly it's the number of people shouting or typing the word 'noob'
Yes, the game has objectives like CS:GO, Red & Blue teams like TF2 but the combat reminds me of CoD more than either of those two.

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is Splash Damage's latest FPS.  Like Enemy Territory before it, Dirty Bomb is a fast-paced, team oriented game where offense has to escort, capture, or destroy a series of objectives in order to win a map. Movement speed is fast and weapon spread very low, resulting in very frantic gameplay.

Splash Damage has made the same game basically four times now in different packages, so the game has built on the qualities of prior games (and learned from failures, not to mention any names...). This particular iteration has turned out really good. A lot of the issues with prior games by Splash Damage I felt have been the maps more than anything else. Balance on asymmetrical maps is a very, very hard thing to do but this game manages to do it well. The number of times a game will come down right to the wire is truly amazing. Win or lose, unless the teams are completely and utterly stacked, there are fun moments to be had.

As far as how the game is monetized... you get two free characters, Skyhammer and Aura, and two heroes on random rotation. You can unlock more characters permanently by accumulating enough of the ingame currency through playing. Additionally, loadouts come on cards. You get the cards in cases which are random drops, or you can buy them with in-game or real money. If you want a specific loadout you can buy them, but it costs more. There are higher tier cards too, but these cards are cosmetic only. Is it pay to win? Not really. They should probably let you have an objective specialist type character to start since it's such an important role, but there isn't one. There's a bit of a grind, but it's probably the most fair way to do everything. For free to play it's rather nonintrusive.

Free to Play just keeps getting better and better, and Dirty Bomb is just the latest example of it. Whether you're a skeptic or not, the game's worth trying. There's nothing to lose after all, and the game is a total of 3GB. If you're a fan of fast paced FPS this is definitely worth a look.

reviewText: Fast paced, team-based shooter. If Counter-Strike, Team Fortress and Call of Duty would have a baby, it would be Dirty Bomb. Very smooth gameplay, nice variety of classes and weapons and a good level-up system. There are also random case-drops so you can get new loadouts. Best point: You can open the cases for FREE. Beside that, even without paying real money via ingame transactions or buying the ~30 bucks DLC on Steam, you earn enough gold to buy new stuff. This game is a fair f2p shooter with nice mechanics and without pay to win. Check it out!

reviewText:
I have a couple of thoughts I wanted to share now that I have played this game for a few hours.

Positives:
+ game runs smooth, no framedrops noticed yet
+ art design and character design is great
+ very nice sound set
+ clear level design, options to flank opponents given
+ class based gameplay
+ objectives make for diverting rounds
+ gunplay feels solid
+ movement feels fluid and not clunky
+ walljumps open up new paths

Negatives:
- menu design is cluttered and confusing
- graphical settings need more in-depth options
- movement options are unintuitive (toggled sprint and crouch)*
- quickmatch function is not working properly
- lack of progression
- no character customisation
- ludicrous shop prices (in-game currency)
- loadouts completely based on RNG
- inability to change loadouts in-game
- no freedom of gun choice
- overlapping classes
- unspectacular class skills, lack of innovation
- partly annoying synchronisation
- questionable balance

*Your character will always sprint/crouch when you use the toggled option until you press the button again, my gripe here is that e.g. usually one stops sprinting when released 'W'.

This game relies way too hefty on RNG. The card loadout system feels contra-productive. Your whole experience will have its roots on RNG, it's up to you how you feel about that. I fore one, think it is misplaced in a fps game.
There is a complete lack of customisation, you can't change your characters loadout unless you have another card for him, which you will only receive via crates you get by leveling up your account or purchasing them in the store.
It should be noted that those are completely RNG based as well, meaning you can't choose for which character you want a crate.
The merc prices are just ridiculous, it goes up to 50.000 credits for a merc to unlock.
To put this in perspective, a crate costs 1000, you will receive around 100 per match. Meaning if you want to unlock e.g. Fragger, you have to save 50.000 credits and you will have to play the whole time with the exact same loadout with the few characters you got.
The grind in this game is unreal, furthermore it is not rewarding nor is there any 'wow' factor, since higher cards only offer more passive skills for your character which in case of a fps game, they are rather marginal and not noteworthy.

At it's current state I don't see how this game could possibly spark my interest to the point where this could become an evening game for me. There is no progression, no customisation, un-innovative classes and skills.

Dirty Bomb tries to hard to copy existing games, while failing to develope it's own character and charm.

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is one hell of a game
Are you tired of playing mindless shooters where people don't do objective play?

Are you tired of getting insulted that you have a negative K/D?

Are you tired of <insert random rant>?

Then this game is perfect for you!

Play the objective, end up top of the list with a score of 10 000 and a fantastic K/D of 2/36. n00bs will say that you suck, but you are tearing their tears apart by being one step ahead of them. Their Sodium Chloride tears will be so tasty that you will keep playing the objective and end up on top of each scoreboard.

FAST PACED GAMEPLAY. If you're used to slow paced shooters, boy will you have a hard time. Things can go so fast, you can be aiming at a Proxy (a super fast eningeer and really annoying but super loveable) and in 2 seconds she is behind you and knifes you. reviewText:
Ok, so im gonna keep it simple. This game is probably the best free2play fps at steam as of right now hands down.
The game is deep enough to keep you coming back to it, and when I say deep enough I'm saying that you can kill your opponent in soo many different ways and move around the map with walljumps/trickjumps (Yes, there is walljumping in this game) and this gets addictive fast!!

There is NO Pay2Win in this game what so ever, there is loadout cards you can buy for credits(ingame currency) or real money. You can also get theese cards from cases that drops every now and then as you play the game. Theese cards come in different colours, they change the skin of your merc by switching colour and they change the weapon and perks, hence the name loadout card.
You can buy elite cases for real money and they will reward you with a silver or higher card, its all up to RNG.

The characters in this game is called mercs, and every merc is unique in their way. They have abilitys unique to them aswell.
There are fast mercs, slow mercs, alot of hp mercs and mercs with less hp.
If the merc has a small health pool they are very fast instead, if they have a big pool they are slow. You get the picture!

If you wanna see some gameplay just head to my stream @ twitch.tv/spdzr . I stream this game every day at 7.00pm utc+1. Thanks for reading and if you have any more questions just ask away in my stream and i will answer.

Have a good one!

reviewText:
If you like a fast paced objective based shooter with classes, then look no further!

Dirty Bomb has Payload, Capture the flag (1 side), and repearing objectives, and depending on the map you can either have to repair, then paylord the EV and finally deliver an objective.
So there's a good mix in maps with objective types.

Sadly, this also means your favorite class, or Merc, might be useless on that map, like Arty in Underground, due to the map having no sky, so you can't call down a bombardment of the area.

Now, it has that TF2 kind of vibe, but there's no med packs lying around, but there's ammo crates stationed in corners.
And medics are very valuable!

There are some balance quirks that needs tuning, but so far it's a very enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb (also known as 'Extraction') - What, who, how?
--------------------------------------------------------------

Dirty Bomb is a free to play & class-based first person shooter developed by the company Splash Damage. You might remember that company from titles such as: Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory"
date: "Enemy Territory: Quake Wars" and "Brink".\n\nThe main goal of this game is to complete multi-staged objectives as a team. I've noticed that if a team just goes around doing what they desire to do
recommended: you'll probably fail on even capturing/completing the first objective. That said
hoursPlayed: to have these multi-stage objectives you need big maps. And big doesn't always mean good
voteText:
but Splash Damage have tried their upmost on most of these maps & have succeeded in many of them. Hats off to them.

So this game is a class-based fps where the players are divided into 2 teams: 'Attackers' & 'Defenders'. This means that the 'Attackers' have to complete a series of objectives in a certain amount of time. While the 'Defenders' must stop the 'Attackers' from doing so.
From what I've played I can tell that your team needs to consist of a certain amount of 'mercs' (these are the different classes) to be able to push & capture/complete an objective.

For example there are a few mercs that have a special ability called: 'Objective Specialist'. This means that those mercs will capture/complete an objective far quicker than a normal merc would.
Basically each merc has their unique capabilities to thelp their team complete the objectives.
* The Fragger pushes with grenades & takes out the enemy & their defences.
* The Medic supports their team by reviving the players & giving out health.
* The Skyhammer clears out huge areas by air-striking them
& so on

On to the gamemodes
- Objective
I already explained this one a few paragraphs above.

- Stopwatch
This gamemode is very similar to the Objective game mode
helpfulPercent:
but 2 games are played. In the 2nd game the Attackers & Defenders switch sides & try to complete the objectives in a faster time than the previous team.

- Competetive
There is a also a competetive gamemode where you & 4 friends/random players will queue up against 5 other players. A Stopwatch game will be played on a randomly chosen map and after a few competetive matches you will get a 'rank'. This rank will tell you what skill level you are and it will match you up with players of the same skill.

On the the business model
There are 15 mercs available in game & you start of with 2 free ones. Skyhammer & Aura. There is also a weekly rotation of 2 to 3 mercs. That means that for an entire week you can play These 3 mercs for free and after that week those mercs are exchanged for 3 others.

But what if you want to play a certain merc for more than a week? Well you can buy that merc for real money or ingame currency. You can earn this currency by playing matches in any of the game modes. Each day you also get a couple missions that you can complete by playing the game
votesHelpful: after every complete mission you get a certain amount of currency. Once you have purchased a merc (prices are 30 & 50 thousand ingame currency) you own it for good.\n\nBut wait there is more. Each merc has a large number or loadout cards that change the primary
votesTotal:
secondary & melee weapon as well as a few extra added 'augments' (these are certain skills that will help your merc in some things like giving out extra ammo packs or having more healing power on the med packs).
The loadout cards come in different qualities.

* Default: every merc starts with a default card & have 0 augments
* Lead: 1 augments & desert camo
* Iron: 2 augments & khaki camo
* Bronze: 3 augments & forest green camo
* Silver: 3 augments & carbon fiber camos
* Gold: 3 augments & gold camo
* Cobalt: 3 augments & blue camo
* Obsidian: Obtainable via a promotion only & 3 augments

You can get these cards by opening cases. There are 2 kinds of cases
votesFunny: an equiment case & an elite case.\n- The equipment case can give you any card (except for the Obsidian one) & can be acquired by just playing the game or you can buy them for 1000 ingame currency.\n- The elite case gives you a silver
commentsCount: gold or cobalt card & can be purchased for ingame money.\n\nIn conclusion: Dirty Bomb is a innovative game in the fps type of games. It adds a few new & funky things to a otherwise normal & dull Call of Duty Modern Warfare 68. The gameplay is solid & polished
column16:
a few lag spikes and connection issues here and there (but that is normal for any game). The graphics are in a sort of cartoon style which makes the game more easy to look at (for me at least). It's a good game in it's category with a smart business model & nice gameplay.

Muffs

Edit 1: As you can probably read I only have about 30 hours in the game. This however isn't totally true because I've played about 150 hours in the closed beta of the game!
Please keep this in mind when judging my review. Thanks!"

reviewText:
After playing it for a lil while I can safely say that DB is a super solid, mechanically rich, just all around fun and hilariously goofy F2p FPS. Now don't let the fact that its f2p put you off, because even though its kinda grindy(around 20hrs to permanently unlock most characters if you're a skilled player) it's absolutely not p2w in any way, because free players get the exact same treatment as premium with an assortment of unique characters all of which you'll eventually get to try out on rotation sooner or later before buying them. The character cards' bonus stats are fairly well balanced in the sense that you can still do good with a default build because it always seems to come down to skill in my experience. These character cards are obtained through cases which you get simply for playing the game or by trading up your previously obtained cards with in-game gold for your desired characters. IMO whats really cool about this game is how ALL the characters are OP if they're played to their strengths, they're all unique with their special perks/abilities and TF2 style appearances. The maps' design is top notch and the game modes are designed to encourage objective play. Also the movement feels really tight with the ability to perform wall jumps and bunnyhops. So if you're in the market for a fun team based fps this is it!

Some of my gameplay as Sparks, a sniper medic...

==========================================================
Update review 6/6/15 open beta

So as promised here is an updated review.

The good
-Gold is alot easier to get
-New characters
-Solid gun play
-Good selection of guns and abilities

The Bad
-Although each character is unique, they don't feel unique. ( i have a machine gun aura that plays alot like the other medic).
-I still find that I either get rolled or do the rolling, balance still needs work
-Maps get old fast
-I am not sure why but I find thise game boring ( mileage may vary)
-Needs new modes as two of the modes are basically the same thing.

The Meh
-You have to double ready for the game, not a bad point but not a good one either
-Why does the game feel the need to remind me of the objective everytime i play. There is no need.
-Not sure why but spawn time vary greatly. Insta died just out of spawn and it took 20secs to respawn, other times is like 2-5 secs.


While I won't be playing the game myself, I can say that it is worth a try to see if its up your alley. At this point, I still can't recommend this game unless you really need a shooter. I'd wait until at least full release to try, as at that point there should be more maps and better balance.

reviewText:
I downloaded Dirty Bomb expecting another soulless free-to-play FPS game that I could put a couple hours into whenever I felt like mindlessly shooting things.
In that regard, I was dissapointed. My expectations were exceeded a thousand-fold.
This game is exactly what games under the free-to-play model should strive for; a solid experience for all players that the dedicated will gladly hand over cash for. Its pricing model reminds me of MOBA giant League of Legends- you have a few characters unlocked from the get-go, and get to sample a few extras every week, and you can unlock your favorites slowly with free currency, or unlock them instantly for cash.
But Dirty Bomb's respect for its players and their wallets are of course not the only reason for my reccomendation. The game is unique, balanced and, most importantly, fun!
Players start each match by selecting three of the mercs" that they have unlocked. Each merc has strengths and weaknesses that will determine the player's role on the field. Skyhammer
date: the first character the player meets in the tutorial
recommended: is a basic fighter/assault character with a fairly high HP and a rifle with decent mid-range capabilities. He can supply his teammates with ammo packs and call in airstrikes. This latter ability is Skyhammer's "unique" power. Every character has a distinct ability as well as one shared by other
hoursPlayed: similar characters.\nMy personal favorite
voteText: Sparks
helpfulPercent: is a quick healer character armed with an SMG and a unique ability that allows her to revive teammates from range. She is easily dispatched
votesHelpful: but if you work with a team full of assaults that know their roles
votesTotal: she can be extremely effective on the field despite her squishiness.\nOnce your squad is selected
votesFunny: you are dropped into a game and tasked with either completing a list of objectives or delaying the enemy team from doing so. Depending on the map
commentsCount: your team will either be rushing to move a cart or plant and defend a bomb or carry batteries or drugs...the game is very dynamic in this regard.\nAdding to this dynamic nature is map-specific side-objectives that can turn the tide for one team or another. Running along the side of a map to the objective as Sparks
column16: I noticed a platform indicating possible interaction. I pressed the action button and built a bridge to another section of the map that was previously only accesible by the enemy team. My team then rushed up the new bridge and dispatched the sniper that had been giving everyone trouble the whole game.\n\nThis game is currently in beta but it is already a fantastic experience
column17: and if you're on the fence about downloading
column18: I'd say it is 100% worth a try."

reviewText:
After around 15 hours, I think it's safe to clock in a quick review.
The game's really fun. I anticipate putting in a bit of time, and I'm definitely hoping there's a competitive league or set of tournaments of sorts. I mean, I'm starting out at the Gold 5 rank. Why let that go to waste? Well, let me list off my list of pros, cons, and maybe hope a dev might see some of my grievances, and maybe we can learn about some of their choices in the game. I'd love to see this game thrive.

PROS The game plays fast. Very, VERY fast. Skill in tracking is a requirement, not an option.
A wide variety of mercs with individual skillsets, and all in all you can play your own way...I stuck to Sawbonz right off the bat.
The community's fairly good. Few rotten apples, but that's in every community.
The ranked matchmaking is very fun. Not quite finished yet, but hey, it's beta.
Movement is very fluid. It's FUN to go from point A to point B. Remember to run with your knife out!
Heavily skill-based (aside from a few classes...)
Easy to run, even on a lower end PC.
Loadout cards to give your character a nice loadout, each with its own weapons and abilities.
Devs seem to like to interact with the community.
And best of all? IT'S FREE!

CONS (kind of, more or less minor gripes) Some major balancing issues, namely with Aura and Nader. They're both a little bit OP. Aura's default shotgun is way too powerful, and Nader's ability to just spam to no end is worse than demos who only use stickies in TF2. What's worse is those grenades insta-kill most of the time.
The game clearly isn't the most stable yet. I've had a few chugs here on a GTX 970/i5-4590 @ 3.30GHz. It isn't common, though, and for what it stands here in beta, the game runs very well.
Microtransactions can be a thing, or you can grind FOREVER to get the merc you want. It gives the illusion of pay to win. Luckily, this is semi-subverted by the fact that by level 5 in EXP, you can have the one merc you wanted, and it'll keep you happy for a long while. Also, there are some mercs who get put into rotation for free every couple weeks, and it always keeps things fresh for gameplay. I intend on maining Sawbonz for a while, especially if I go into a league, support medic seems to be my thing!
The unboxing reminds me too much of CS:GO. Stop giving me Lead Fletchers please ;-;

The Final Verdict! Dirty Bomb is quite possibly one of the best F2P shooters I've played in a long time. I used to love TF2 to death, but now...I don't know. The fast-paced gameplay combined with the skill required to aim, the coordination in matchmaking that me and my friends can pull off is just something that I can't define. It's easy to get sucked in, and that's the type of game I like. I'm considering dropping a little cash on it to support the devs, I mean, it's a free game, and it's really the only way they can make money without putting ads into the game. I'd like to know if and or when we'll be getting the ability to put up our own servers, and who knows, maybe a league can take off from there! But for now, I'd like to see the game exit beta safely. The game has a lot of potential as it stands, and while a few characters require nerfs (*cough* Aura and Nader, Aura needs her shotgun to be weakened, Nader needs a longer skill cooldown *coughcough*), the game is very balanced, and very enjoyable on that note for what it is. This is a game I'd HIGHLY recommend to anybody who is a fan of FPS games, and who knows, if the devs keep it up we could have an amazing game, with an amazing competitive side.

Just whatever you do, Splash Damage, do NOT rush this game, please. This game's too good, and I do not want it to die.




TL;DR: Get this game. It's fun, fast-paced, and enjoyable. It has micro transactions and a couple of imbalances, but it still calls for a good time.
