reviewText:
This is a free to play, (pay to progress - but only to speed up progress) fast paced and highly competitive first person shooter. Dirty Bomb features mercenaries tasked with retrieving or destroying objectives in return for credits in a London devastated by a - you guessed it - dirty bomb. There are currently five maps in rotation with several more in development & testing, but they all provide a fairly balanced and fun layout to play with, and the new maps look to be getting even larger - which will be good hopefully!

There are three gamemodes currently; Stopwatch, Objective and the newly added / still in testing Execution game mode - Stopwatch revolves around both teams trying to complete the objectives for the chosen map faster than their opponent, after which they switch sides (attackers to defenders) and the winner is decided on the faster team.

Objective mode is simply stopwatch without the team switch, and as such one team defends the objective, the other attacks it until time runs out or all objectives are complete.

Execution mode is relatively new, and consists of 10 rounds where the teams attempt to win more rounds than the other, by playing the objective or killing all the enemies on the map. This mode has the added rule that when you die, and are 'gibbed' (stabbed so that a medic cannot revive you), you will need to wait til the next round begins to continue playing. Medics can revive provided you are not executed, alá the game mode title.

Enough about the modes, you probably understand the only thing you need to: objective - uhb-jek-tiv, play that and you win. Simple!

Onto the characters, or mercs. There are currently 14 mercs available for play, with the newest being Phantom - a stealthy melee oriented class who has caused some controversy as to what the game is aiming for. The mercs each have a subcategory which are as follows:

- [Fire] Support classes:
* Arty, whom can call down artillery with his targeting designator from afar and provide his team with ammo via ammo packs.
* Kira, who loves to light up the sky with her orbital laser strike, which she can guide around using the laser tool to cause maximum precision chaos from safety. She also deploys ammo stations to keep teammates well stocked throughout the fight.
* Skyhammer, one of the free mercs you get right off the bat, who has the ability to throw an airstrike marker to gib and demolish his foes, and also damage certain objectives such as generators and the EV when defending (Kira and Arty can also damage these objectives). Skyhammer will oft throw ammo packs like his fellow support class Arty.

- Recon classes:
* Vassili, the sniper-est sniper there ever was, Vassili was the first of the recon classes added to open play, and can be devastating to enemy pushes if he can aim and position well. His heartbeat sensor can be vital to knowing enemy movements.
* Phantom, the all-American hero in his own mind, this backstabber is aimed at executing medics and other squishy vital classes. His ability is a cloak that makes him fairly invisible. The cloak can be removed with Vassili's heartbeat sensor if the two come in close proximity.

- Medic classes:
* Aura, the shotgun wielding, heal station hero, who keeps the team healed and happy, alive, not dead. Her main ability is a healing station she can place nigh almost anywhere on the map which heals in a small radius, and can almost outheal all damage sources if placed right. She can also revive fallen teammates with the defib paddles. Aura, along with Skyhammer is one of the mercs you get for free!
* Sawbonez, the ex-military CQC SMG-specialist who throws large healing packs, potent enough to bring even the most deathly ill back to the land of the living, and doing it with style. Sawbonez - with a Z! - also holds the key to close range life and death with his defib paddles.
* Sparks, the super fast gal with a hundred names, and a wonderful piece of reviving and sniping technology. Sparks can reanimate people from afar with her REVIVR gun, which when charged is equally as good at reviving teammates as it is at killing enemies. Sparks has far less potent healing packs in contrast to Sawbonez, but they are no less helpful in a pinch.

- Engineer classes:
* Proxy, the savvy and snappy Brit who loves to sap the lives of her foes via proximity mines strewn across the map, Proxy is also an objective specialist who has a 50% boost to completing objectives (such as repairing generators).
The objective specialist is present on all engineer classes.
* Fletcher, who is the best. That's why he costs more! No but seriously, Fletcher is an engineer with an explosive surprise: sticky bombs! Create traps alá Proxy style, cover objectives or doorways that are important, or else use them as renewable grenades!
* Bushwacker, the man with the extra gun. Bushwacker comes equipped with a turret buddy who can be placed almost anywhere needed, but for best results, try placing them on flank routes or behind where you will be fighting, and get a nice crossfire going. The turret is fairly weak healthwise, but can pack a good punch with its firepower if placed right.

- Assault classes:
* Nader, the business lawyer turned merc who has a renewable (don't ask me how) grenade launcher which can spit little eggs of death! Or was that dess? I'm not bilingual I'm afraid. Nader can shut down areas of defense and offense if her nades are utilised correctly, and even if she dies, she comes back post mortem with an explosive surprise called matyrdom, where she detontates herself and any nearby enemies!
* Fragger, the traffic cop, uh no, sorry; the man with the second biggest gun! His parking tickets - no wrong again! His frag grenades will cause chaos and death if cooked for long enough, and his LMG does nothing to ease the enemy's pain (except perhaps a quick death?). Many soon find out why Fragger is called what he is.
* Rhino, now for the man with the biggest gun, Rhino is a monster of a man who can hold entire areas if paired with a medic such as Aura with his minigun, which doesn't run dry on ammo, and instead can overheat quickly if used wrongly. Rhino is the merc with the most health, and as such, should not be taken lightly.


Didn't realise how much I had written up until now, so TL;DR if you want it!

TL;DR: Dirty Bomb is a crazy fun F2P FPS, which has an alright business model where you can pay to progress faster (unlock characters quicker) and it provides a decently balanced game for the most part, where each character feels powerful, and matches that are all objective focused feel tense right down to the last second. Also, to mention one last thing - there is a certain movement to the game where walljumping is possible, which adds a layer or two to fighting. Thought it was worth a mention.

Great game, hope it does well in the future!

EDIT: Changed phantom's description due to patch fixes.

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is quite an anomaly in the F2P arena. It has solid mechanics and base gameplay. Everything is accessible to everyone. You do have to have to buy new characters to use and loadouts (which vary up the weapon selection and minor perks), but the time it takes seems fair. There are plenty of missions that rotate every three hours and daily bonuses that allow you to rack up 1000s of credits every day in addition to receiving credits for just playing. A new merc will take you about 1-2 weeks to unlock if you time your missions right.  If you don't want to use in-game credits for this, there is the option to spend real world money. This does seem a bit high for what you get though and I recommend getting the bundle when it goes on sale. You're not at a loss for choice though at the start. You get Aura (a medic) and Skyhammer (a fire support class / jack of all trades type) permanently for free in addition to three rotating mercs that are freely available and change up every few weeks.

The feel of the game is quite smooth. There are plenty of trickjumps and shortcuts to find on the various maps. Just about every weapon is hitscan. This means that damage is dealt directly to whatever it is you click on. You can generally take several shots before dying and with a medic nearby to revive you, you're never too long removed from the action. It's similar in several ways to Enemy Territory, another free game released a decade ago by the same team, that was hugely popular as well as TF2. There are similar classes that you can choose from. Medics revive and heal. Assault dishes out damage as well as taking it. Fire support provides your team with ammo and helps destroy objectives and whole teams from afar. Engineers repair much faster as well as planting/defusing bombs. And Recon helps your team with map awareness and picking off enemies from a distance. Lots of basic functionality is shared across the classes and there's plenty of combinations to choose from if you're looking for something that'll fit your playstyle.

Finally, the community itself is fairly laid-back and welcoming. Especially compared with other FPSes I've played. And I've been playing since the 90s. This is likely a result of how small it is. There's something like 3-4k players on typically. Just enough to have a decent selection of servers across multiple maps and game modes. In addition to there being pick-up games you can find being formed across the many community voice servers if you're looking for more of a challenge.

There is some hitching with certain combinations of hardware and software. It's recommended that you get a CPU that is very powerful on one core at least. The latest quad-core from Intel overclocked a decent amount should allow consistent 144 fps and up. A mid-range GPU should suffice. I can personally run this at 1440p @ 144hz on a 4930k @ 4.3ghz and a 7970 ghz Edition @ 1165 Core / 1575 Memory. I generally get up to 200fps with this setup and the GPU runs at about 40-60% usage.

This is probably among the better deals in not only F2P games, but more expensive ones as well. TF2 players will love it for the similarly fast paced action and the different classes provided. CS:GO players will enjoy the small teams and similar weaponry that they are already used to. Not to mention the greatly reduced recoil. While alternatives exist in the rapidly expanding genre of class-based shooters, Dirty Bomb has that perfect fit of fast action and teamplay that I find lacking elsewhere.

tl;dr

Solid shooter, no power advantages via cash like in other F2P shooters, great community. Oh, did I mention it's free?

reviewText:
While the game is worth giving a try, I can't recommend it.  Like with a lot of F2P games, new players will be shephered into noobie friendly (and enjoyable) areas and eventually released into the cold brutal reality that is the larger playerbase.

The art style is nice, with good graphics and interesting maps with lots of alternate routes and side objectives.

Perks and loadouts are determined by random drops.  Most of them are minor but there are a few significant perks that make a big difference in the way you can play, and its completely random whether you get them or not.

There is a distinct lack of teamplay in the rounds I played in.  Most of the game is centered around TDM rather than the actual objectives. This is pretty par for the course for modern games though.

The guns feel same-y, which is to say, not very strong.  Headshots are king, as they do not suffer from damage fall off. Therefore, weapons with the fastest firing rate and lowest recoil are the ones players gravitate towards.

Overall I enjoyed myself while I was learning the ropes but quickly stopped enjoying myself once I realized what was going on.

reviewText:
Let's be real.
The main reason why this game has negative reviews is because of the anti-cheat system they have had. But I like the majority have never had a problem with it. You have to consider the fact that the Anti-cheat system has changed. Those reviews was back when it was still in closed beta mode. And in one of its latest updates the developers did know that this was a problem and even told us that they identified as a problem and that they are trying to fix it. So yes they did update the anti-cheat and it's fine

This game is very enjoyable and a big adictive. The graphics mechanics in movements of the mercs are well done. Yes this is a point a shot game, like with nearly all FPS games. This games is a multiplayer game only with 3 modes as of now. Execution, where you only get one life per round as you play attacker or defender in which case the attacker arms the C4 where as the defenders try and stop them from disarming the C4 or defusing it. The Objective mode where the attackers will have to do the objective and defenders stop the attackers from doing it, and stopwatch where it's a timed match of which team can a set of objectives or just one depending the fastest

There are many mercs in this game, each with their abilities. At the moment there are 18 mercs. But i think they will add
more as this is still in development. Each merc is catagorized in different classes. Slayer, which are mercs used soley to kill the enemy. Support, mercs that help their team with their perks or abilites such as giving ammo. Medics, mercs that help your team by giving them health or reviving them. And lastly the Engineers, these are the mercs that are specifically desgined to do the objective or the goal of the match. Unlike the rest of the mercs engineers or objective specialists can arm the C4, defuse the C4, repair the EV (a vehicle which looks like a tank) etc. much quicker.

Each merc has their own set of different abilites that they can use. For example Thunder can throw concussio grande, Vasili who is a sniper can use his heart beat sensor to locat enemies within a range and Fletcher can use his ability to throw stick bombs and defuse them. Just to name a few! These mercs also come with loadout cards which change the type of weapon they have, what they wear, for example the special edition cards form the latest update which you get from cases for the trinket update give your merc a christmas winter look!

So if your a player who likes shooting with variety of special options in this fast pased game (don't worry it's normal once you play) than you will love this game. This game is very fun and enjoyable! And it's only going to get better

No tragedy, no ♥♥♥ breaks.Generally Dirty Bomb is a game for people who like fast and dynamic action. Each player should find a character that will fall to his liking, due to the diversity of mercenaries and their special abilities. CONS:

reviewText:
In my opinion, Dirty Bomb is one of the best f2p First-Person Shooters out right now. There is a lot of variety in most maps and the dynamic objectives are really fun.

There is progression in the game that can give slight advantages to players, but it's not game breaking. I can not say any of those slight advantages ever felt like I lost a fire-fight because of them, and more because I messed up.

With that said, the game is highly skill based and we have a lot of guys who have extremely good aim and will down you very quickly. Working as a team is the best way to win because of the dynamic objectives spread out through them map.

Using your classes strengths to their maximum potential will really highlight what team compositions counter other compositions. Some classes are run and gun and are extremely mobile and will flank  to destroy back line defenses (turrets, mines, health/ammo stations, defibbers). Other classes are slower but have clear power to roll through people who are caught in their fire.

The buddy system isn't implemented yet, well at least not an in-game buddy system. You have to search through Steam's terrible database of all players, and you're lucky if your friends on DB have a unique name. If not, you'll be searching thousands of players on steam, or having to ask them to change their name to something stupid so that you can find them.

Putting money into the game just helps unlock classes and class variations. You can unlock everything with in-game currency so no worries. Putting money does make it easier to unlock the class variation that you want rather than having to spend in-game currency on lock boxes (think CoD chests). Honestly, putting in 5 bucks for your favorite class is an awesome way to support the devs in this incredible game!

Why did I spend so much time typing this -__-

reviewText:
Update:
I should have articulated myself better. Sorry. My nostalgic trip was to highlight all the interesting and creative things I could do in ET. When I compare that to Dirty Bomb I'm just not finding the same scope of gameplay. Obviously Dirty Bomb is a different game but   I find it lacks depth and could be so much more. Splash Damage just makes these types of games so the comparison is always going to be made in my eyes.


I'm a huge ET fan. It's the one game I look back the most fondly. As another review said this is what BRINK should have been and I totally agree. However it just doesn't quite capture the magic of ET. Perhaps I'm wearing rose coloured glasses... But it's the yard stick I measure ALL Splash Damage games with.

I only played Covert Op (enemy in disguise) back in the day and I miss the little things I could do as that class. This is why the magic is missing for ME -> I can't be as creative as I used to be.

- Capture the forward spawn at just the right time
- Deny the enemy information by blowing up the command post at strategic times
- Secondary means of completing the objective - Fuel Dump ;)
- Satchel charge on a group of gunners
- Run through the spawn to get to the objective in an unexpected manner
- Open the back door and sneak key team members in (multiple vectors to complete a mission)
- Fireteam chat (only communicate to key team memebers)
- Spotting hidden mines
- Mind games with the enemy, constantly blowing up the command post and hiding, blocking the doorway when rushing to defuse, pretend to defend an objective for a long period of time
- Hiding in the bushes, spotting mines waiting to pounce
- Smoke grenades (so useful)

This and so much more I could do that I felt made a huge impact on the course of a round. Brutally hard to pull off but so satisfying. It appealed to my lone wolf introverted nature.

In saying that... I'm going to stick with this game, hoping the new mercs bring something new to the table. Red eye and that invisible one look promising.

Currently the game is fast and fun. Some rounds your team are a bunch of muppets and other times they're God's gift to gaming. Mostly it's a fairly balanced game of tug-o-war. But as it stands there are just too many variations of the same merc. Give me tools to be creative.

Still recommend.

(I used to play as 'Borealis' on Aussie servers if anyone remembers)

reviewText:
This game is certainly fun but there are some things that have to be changed for it to be enjoyable.

-Balance

Most of my games are unbalanced player whise.
I want to join a 8v8 game and end up in a 4 v 5 more often than anything other.
A lot of maps are really unbalanced. It's most often the case that the defending team has a really easy job defending the objectives and the attacking team has a major disadvantage and can't win without a massive skill advantage.
The best example is the truck you have to repair and escort to the objective. You need up 20 seconds to repair that thing and it's allready broken after one airstrike. A coordinated team can keep this thing in one place for the whole game by only hitting the airstrike markers in the right time.

Thats it no other points for me to nag on.
This game is fun as long as it's balanced, which is rare.
Don't let people tell you its p2w. You can easily craft bronze cards which have no disadvantages to silver, gold or cobalt other than the skins. The mercs are expensive but the ones in the rotations are allways enough to have fun.
If they fix the balance issues it could be something big.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Dirty Bomb is a Free to Play, Multiplayer, First Person Shooter, developed by Splash Damage and Open Beta was released 2015 on steam.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: The game takes place in a post-apocalyptic wasteland in London, you play as one of the mercenaries trying to get rich, you must work with others to overcome the opposing team to earn your bounty.

Gameplay: There are about 19 playable Mercs in Dirty Bomb, however only two or three will be available unless you unlock the others by spending in-game currency, or real life currency.
There's a lot that can be said for the play style of each character, they're all distinct and have different abilities that can be used to help your team. I spent most of my time as the Medic. (I'm actually not the “healing” type of gamer, but I've always scored best being able to keep myself and others alive, and I also have a good track record of rezzing people in the clutch.) As a Medic you can drop an AoE (Area of Effect) Heal for your team mates, and provide almost instant resurrections. (As is getting increasingly popular in games; you're first “downed” and then “dead” after a few seconds being downed... or being finished off before that timer)

There are several different types of maps you play in Dirty Bomb, Capture the flag, Base Defense, cart ride... but with a twist. Sometimes you need to defend a tank that also operates as mobile turret, other times you're trying to disarm key strategic choke holds that keep changing before the game is won or lost, trying to disarm a bomb, and more.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=497802359

Achievements: At this point there are no steam achievements for Dirty Bomb, however there are daily challenges you can go for to earn extra in-game currency, and there's an experience reward system that will help make sure you're facing people with familiar-skill-levels, but also providing a sense of progression.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=502991679

Price: Dirty Bomb is Free to Play, many people will object to any type of “spend real money” model in a Free to Play business model – I guess we'll need to agree to disagree on the semantics, if the game is free and don't shake me down for money, I don't think of it as “pay to win” unless paying will make it impossible for me to play the game(I'm looking at you ...facebook app games...!). The game does let you earn in-game currency to unlock the various features instead of just spending real money on these items, but I didn't find myself cursing someone because they were using a Merc I didn't have unlocked.

Conclusion: All in all, I enjoyed playing Dirty Bomb. It's very similar to other FPS we all know and love...ish, like Team Fortress 2, or Counter Strike. However it stands on it's own and is a fun change of pace from the aforementioned. Since it's free it's an easy pick-up and then put-down. I recommend Dirty Bomb to FPS junkies.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=497802376
voteText: 15 of 22 people (68%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This one is not even a close call; As the first person shooter market is stalled for years by now, I would say we were in dire need for a new and refreshing game to the genre.
Dirty Bomb is a class, team based, objective focus FPS that brings a mash up of features and mechanics that just work well together, allow me to explain:
- The maps are big, multiple staged, and overall well design and well balanced, offering inumerous ways to place with one, providing a different game everytime you take your Mercs into one.
-The movement system is fluid and responsive, with each Merc moving differently from one another, and the wall jump mechanic is the the icing on the cake: so simple to use, really hard to master, a stapple that makes the really great players stand out from the best.
-The guns and the gunplay are really satisfying, as they not only sound but also and look powerfull. The fact that you can't oneshot an enemy with most weapons lays a foundation to some quick, nerve racking firefights, making each kill a really satisfying to pull of.
-The classes appear to be pretty balanced, each one of them occupying a unique place and, above all, they all fit usefull purpose inside the game. Not surprising since they all tend to fit the overall classic FPS archtypes of classes.
-The business model is fair and the in-game rewards such as cases and in-game currency come at a really steady and generous pace, with quests refreshing really often, offering players a great incentive to keep on playing.

But the game is not without it's flaws, I shall explain those too:
-The weapon variety could be way larger and the futuristing setting can lead to some creative liberty while designing them, so a little more inovation in this field could improve the game much, much more.
-The sound design, while good, could use some improvement too. As some weapons clearly sound powerfull, others sound weak and tend to lack that meaty, satisfying *THUMP* that firing a weapon should always carry.

One can't help but grade Dirty Bomb as a really great, innovative and above all, a really, really fun First Person Shooter that bring a breath of fresh air to a genre that clearly needs it. I can't stop recommend it enough. Play it! Get Dirty! And remember, Don't be a D*ck!

reviewText:
More Impressions @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

Feeling the need for a new FPS to fill your life? Dirty Bomb is gearing up to be another great option for the gamer that doesn’t like to spend too much money. With its FTP option and an increasing amount of characters, levels and modes, the people over at Splash Damage look like they are trying their darnedest to create a solid and full game when it finally leaves Beta status.

The level design is what stands out to me the most about Dirty Bomb. Each level has a great amount of detail put into it with little touches here and there to make each alley, room and building different from the last. They also have a few places that make good use of the ability to use your double or triple wall-jump ability. (I’m getting a good hang of the double jump, the triple is a little beyond me at the moment.) So far the levels have a good enough build quality that stops people from getting into places that one should not… but we’ll see how that goes when it gets released to the masses.

You may be wondering how Dirty Bomb is drawing you and when the PTW trap is going to spring into action. Well, so far it looks like that issue isn’t going to rear its ugly head. There is a bit of an exp grind, but so far the only useful thing leveling up gets you is the ability to group up with your buddies and jump into Stopwatch Mode together. What can you buy then? Well for now you can get a few characters and 35k credits for $20 ($40 on release I believe). You can also buy cases that give a chance at random quality character cards which give you different weapon loadouts, special qualities and aesthetics, but that's with in-game money so nevermind. (Thank you Rune for pointing out my blunder!)

Here’s where a small issues comes up for me. I like that cases can be bought or received from drops in-game after the match is over, the randomness is kind of wonky. You don’t get a choice of every single card in the game. When you open the case you get a random assortment of cards and only one gold card that comes around twice (most likely to end before or just eek by before the spinning stops). So if you dig Nadder, you may not come across a gold Nadder card very often. Then again… it’s random, but the game has no problem giving you the same card for the same character over and over again. (What kills me is if the character bonuses are what I want, but it’s with a gun I hate.) Luckily you can trade up your cards for another random card (for some in-game money of course) for the character of your choosing. So while it may not have the guns or stats you want… it will at least be a character you wanted. It’s a neat way to implement differences in playstyle for yourself (everyone else still seems to run around and kill you so I don’t notice it much in others).

My main issue in the game is the match-making/team balancing and the cheating. Match making doesn’t seem to be implemented at this point too much, but even if it is, you can still swap sides before a match and create what may be an unbalanced team. That goes without saying and there’s not much the devs can do about that other than drop the feature, which would be goofy. I like playing with my buds and I’m sure the rest of you do as well. However, if a match is too one-sided and people leave there is not auto-balance feature either. If three people peace out during a match then you’re just out of luck because you can’t switch teams in the middle of a match. People can join, but I don’t notice that very often. Most joining happens at the beginning of the match and if you’re down three halfway, then you’re probably down for the rest of the match and that can suck a lot.

The cheating is something I haven’t fully experienced until more recently. If it was going on before a few weeks ago, I hadn’t come across it (and I miss those times). Recently there have been a noticeable number of people who just can’t help but get head-shots. There is no reporting someone in this game and I bet there will be no perma-bans by the devs. What’s worse is that the players (on some level) may be OK with it. Now, it could just be that when it’s being done to you, it’s more obvious and you want it to stop. That makes sense. When it’s your team that has the cheater, you may not notice until the complaints happen in the chat window (if you can play a frenetic FPS and read everything in chat that is…). Only the team with the cheater can vote to kick someone and sometimes people will vote no because they either want an easy win, think it’s funny or simply don’t notice the small vote window in the top-left corner. In one round I played a day ago we tried to boot someone and it failed five or six times. I just left, I didn’t want to win like that. Someone said that since this is a Nexxon game that there will be an issue with cheating and now that it’s reared its ugly head I guess we’ll see if the devs take it seriously enough. I want to believe they will since some of the players don’t seem to, which is very lame.

This is coming off as rather negative, but I’ve had a fun 32 hours in the game so far and I do intend to play it a bit longer, but I am curious on how they will proceed from here…

PS: Pick a server with low ping, it seriously helps a lot. I’ve managed in other shooters to play in servers with 300-400 ping, but while this game looks smooth with high ping the bullets and other sorts of things do not work like they should. I know that sounds like common sense, but like I said, I’ve played other shooters back in the day with higher ping and didn’t have a problem. Dirty Bomb doesn’t do well with high ping. It’s a good thing there is always another server open!

Score: Support This Title!

With great gun-play, level design and characters with different loadouts, Dirty Bomb is looking great. It’s a load of fun and neat to see that a team of healers can be a pain in the butt again. The randomness with the cards can suck a lot, but seeing as how you don’t need to have a gold card to do awesome, it’s not too bad. Just keep upgrading those bronze ones mates! Depending on how they handle the cheating will strongly determine the fate of Dirty Bomb. Let’s hope they have some huge fix and or plan to implement that will encourage people to play better with each other. This is a FTP game and that normally does bring in a certain type, but if you can get in free Dirty Bomb is well worth it. Right now you can buy in for $20 and I can think of a lot of other games I’ve spent less on and didn’t have as much fun. At $20, Dirty Bomb is still worth a try.

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is F2P game developed by Splash Damage, the studio behind Enemy Territory, and is published by  Nexon America. The game itself is full of action and is set at an incredibly fast pace. It pits 2 teams of 6-8 players against one another, one attacking and the other defending and each player must use a Merc who has varying weapons, skills and augments.

Sounds like Team Fortress 2 almost doesn't it? Well it's not,because we don't have a million weapons and hats ruining our steam inventory and meta game balancing. As good as the F2P market is locked down by TF2 and DOTA, Dirty Bomb IMO is a good competitor as it has the action, the easy to grasp controls, its quick and easy to get into the game, easy to learn hard master, as is the motif with character skill based games. But i can also understand why it's not as popular as it could be, mostly with balancing issues, an illusion of P2W and sometimes really bad matchmaking.

Gameplay
Like I have said before, the gameplay is set at a very fast paced, but it's balanced in a way that can make it slow. It's normal to see people jumping off and over walls to get to better positions, or to increase their speed to get objectives faster. But as often you see that, you will see long corridors of death that defenders are trying to hold for the win, bringing the game down to a slow crawl until you overcome it. It all depends on one team's skill to quickly get into the perfect positions faster than the other team can take advantage of.

When it comes down to pure player skill, it's another thing. You can take things slow, but you will have to learn to pick up the pace, getting into ideal position is important, especially when it comes to setting positions to take on the other team's position. Gunfights at range are very fickle things because of this, grinding through a defenders well fortified position is tough unless the attacker are well skilled, prepared and fast. Fighting them at range is the most promising, but many of the weapons have little damage at range, especially with the damage fall off and aiming down sight doesn't help much against small targets because of the recoil. In fact most the time firing from the hip is your best option. Tracking player movement with your weapons learning their recoil and weapon spread can help, get those headshot right.

Mercenaries
there are close to 20 different mercenaries to choose from, who are split into different categories which are slayer, support, engineer and medic. Each type obviously has different roles to play, slayers only job is to be on the front lines killing everything in their path, engineers go in behind them and complete the game's objectives. Some characters can fill a second role quite easily, Fletcher is an engineer but with his weapons and skills, he quite a capable slayer character too. The characters themselves look incredibly well designed,  heavy hitting mercs are usually large, carrying immense amount of armour and equipment on their backs or body's, smaller mercs are light carrying very little and will zip around the level.

I would be lying when they saying how good many of the mercs, obviously there will be the absolutely best top tier characters who shine anywhere, then there would be the ones who are good at times, then the very situational ones. A top tier example is Fragger, he is a combat power house, 150 health armed with two of the strongest assault rifles in the game and he chucks a very powerful grenade to kill multiple mercs instantly. He just shines no matter what player has him, or what situation, he will will get the job done.

You won't be able to change much about a merc, except maybe their loadout card. This card will have different weapons and augments which can slightly change the style of play the merc can do. There are 9 of them in total, none of them are really OP, there is one that obviously the perfect embodiment of their playstyle, where others tend to make the more aggressive and some just so situational and useless. Obviously the augments are the cause of the change of style, and they are regarded by the community as useless, what actually makes the character good is their skills and the weapons you are most proficient in.

Mercs however are locked, and you must have enough in game credits to unlock them. This is where people become idiots and fail to seek out information which they can get by playing. Credit generation most of the time is slow, I will admit that, you will get at most 150 to 200 per 15 min game, double that on stopwatch, and even more on ranked. Mercs however cost 30k-50k credits, so you can see why people get a bit mad. But Splash does do many things that help settle these woes. Every two weeks they offer 3 mercs on rotation to try for free, they added the ability to earn credits by accomplishing missions, which you get by normal play or by doing specific things, and these refill every few hours and can reward 500-1000 credits per mission. Finally once a day you can claim the first match of the day and first win of the for each of the games which give you 500 credits each.

Game modes
There are 3 Game Modes, objective, stopwatch and execution. There is also the ranked mode but that only has stopwatch games for the moment, and it is unclear if the other modes will be added for future seasons. Objective mode is simple, complete your objective first. Attackers have a multi stage set of objectives which they must complete under a time limit, these being destroy, escort and repair. On the other side, defenders have to stop the attackers accomplishing their objective until the timer runs out.

Stopwatch is the exact same as objective mode with one twist, the attacks have 15min to complete all of their objectives. After which the teams will swap and the once defender now have to beat the attacking team's time, or get further than them if they failed to complete all of the objectives, You can also draw if both teams fail at the same point progress. Execution is the search and destroy of Dirty Bomb, nothing new except for the games mechanics allowing people to be rived and use character and what not.

The maps that you play each have their own charm, as well as their own grind of death point. For some maps this can be the start like in bridge’s funneled corridors in order to get to the ev, or Dome’s pit of death delivery point. Other times it's halfway through the map like church's long street or even train’s blocker carriage. Regardless of attitude you will come across certain of objectives on each map that are just a pain to do. The EV escorts are most hated, largely because their ease of being destroyed by almost everyone with an explosives weapon, which is the vast amount of merc on the roster btw. Still I suppose it's a skill in itself to quickly repair it with an engineer, but it's annoying for the defenders to get a cheap win because they can stack explosive skilled characters.


Conclusion
So what do we have? A well made F2P game, that is still currently in its beta phase, so it's continually adding more mercs and maps, balancing and improving them. It has albeit small but a very dedicated community, its own competitive mode and ranks and the game is very easy to get into and enjoy. But yet we do have a potentially rage inducing game because it doesn't follow the current motif of many shooter games on the market, as well many of the issues i have already stated. In the end its a free game, you lose nothing but time and potentially happiness or boredom by playing, and you could always remove it if you really hate it.

Have a good day :3

reviewText:
Great game. Dont let the free part fool you. It's also NOT pay to win. Fast paced and plenty of characters to play with that keeps the game from getting boring. Dont just play this for an hour or so to decide if you like it. It takes a little time to learn the mechanics and strats like all other games. After a little time you get much better and you will also unlock more characters. Thats when the game opens up and you start enjoying it even more. reviewText:
Let me preface by saying this is the best F2P Shooter I've played in a while, however, that's not saying much, Don't blieve the hype, theres tons of reviews that are like 0.5 to 1.5 hours, they have played like 2 to 3 games.

Main Issues I have with the game are the F2P model, super expensive to purchase one base merc, from 6 to 10 bucks. Secondly, the map flow is HORRIFIC, there are maps that cater to defense and some that cater to attack, like attacking on Trainyard, UGH, it consists of a Sniper in the back of the second attack point or someone on turret, and people dropping skyhammers every 5 seconds. The maps just need redesigning to stop battles from easily becoming stalemates to starve outs.
Third, granted its fresh and is always changing, but the balancing seems to not be prioirty. They would rather release no characters than fix the ones they have, like Buchwacker and Rhino are Broken AF, and like Arty is very underwhelming (mainly due to semi auto being way underpowered vs auto).
I can't recommend the game in its current state, it needs lots of love to its Balance, Map Balance and Design, Business Model and other small things propel it into the Top F2P games on steam.

reviewText:
Some of the most fun I have had in a long while with fps games !
Plus its the ONLY f2p game that is TRUELY FREE TO PLAY !
Set in London
3 Modes - Objective, Execution and Stopwatch
*Execution is like a csgo kinda mode, defuse or plant, one life setup

Mercenaries are cool and can be bought with either real cash OR in game currency
You start with 2 Mercs and you have 3 on free rotation that changes fortnightly
*This gives you a good time to try out mercs and see who you want to save for

There are currently 5 classes:

*Medic - 4 medics [^AURA, PHOENIX, SAWBONEZ and SPARKS]
*Support - 4 Support [ARTY, KIRA, ^SKYHAMMER and STOKER]
*Engineer - 3 Engineers [BUSHWACKER, FLETCHER and PROXY]
*Frag - 5 Frag [FRAGGER, NADER, PHANTOM, RHINO and THUNDER]
*Sniper - 2 Snipers [REDEYE and VASILI]

^denotes mercs you start with

each merc has his or her own special ability!

Ingame currency is NOT HARD TO EARN ! let me break it down for you....

*You earn credits by simply playing matches
*You also earn credits by completing credit missions [3 missions at a time that renew every 3 hours after completion, prizes are 500, 750 or 1000 credits]
*You also earn 1500 for playing one match of each mode [500 each mode]
*Not to mention a nice bonus of 500 credits for your first win of the day.... So thats 2000 per day without counting currency earnt at the end of each match or the missions !!!
*You will also recieve a nice lump sum of credits when you reach level 5.


The Loadout system is very unique and it is alot of fun collecting the cards. They can be aquired in a number of ways just like the mercs..

*You will get random case drops for playing matches [NO FUNDS NEEDED TO OPEN THEM]
*You can trade up old cards for new ones to get rarer bling [YOU CHOOSE WHAT MERC THE NEW CARD WILL BE FOR]
*you can use ingame currency to purchase cards that have a nicer skin on [NOTHING THAT BOOSTS YOU THAT MAKES A BIG DISADVANTAGE TO OTHER PLAYERS]
*Of course if you are impatient you can use cash but I havn't.

Regular events - The last was the What The Dickens" event for christmas

reviewText:
This needs work.

The ugly:

- The menus are clumsy, slow, and not well thought out.
- You cannot play with friends until level 7 (which takes more than a few hours of gameplay).
- The matchmaking and lobby system are lackluster; it often tries to have you join full servers, and it doesn't auto-balance well.
- The server browser is redesigned needlessly and hides all of the important options out of sight (e.g. auto-join).

The bad:

- There's obvious balance issues. Speed and manueverability are the most important in every game mode.
- Some 'Merc' abilities need to be better thought out for indoor scenarios.
- Loadout cards don't feel much different from each other, and many are worse than the default regardless of quality.
- 'Credit' and experience gain seem largely arbitrary, and you get virtually neither for having lost a game (what's the point in continuing to play it?)

The good:

- The objective-based gameplay is fun when you're not being camped or steamrolled.
- The 'Merc' abilities are cool to use even if some are better and more satisfying than others.
- The game is new and different enough to attract interest if it gets everything together.

reviewText:
So there are a few things about this game:

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is a free-to-play class-based multiplayer First Person Shooter from Splash Damage.  The premise of the game is that two teams complete over a series of sequential objectives within a certain time frame.  Players can choose three characters to bring into a match, each of which has a particular pair of abilities that are suited to different battlefield roles.  Each character has a default loadout, and alternative loadouts can be obtained through play time or by purchasing them from the in-game store.  There are three different modes: two, Objective and Stopwatch, are based around maps in which one team attacks 2-3 targets in a certain order while another defends, while the third, Execution, is a Counter-Strike-like mode in which one team tries to destroy one of two bomb sites or kill all members of the enemy team to win.

Dirty Bomb has gotten a bad rap over it's relatively brief lifetime, much of which is undeserved.  One of the main complaints from those who have not actually spent much time playing is that it is pay-to-win.  This is, however, basically untrue.  All characters and loadouts can be permanently unlocked through play time, and at any given time five of the mercs will be available for free: three rotation mercs, and the two defaults, Skyhammer and Aura, both of which are entirely viable against their more expensive counterparts.  Nor does it take a particularly long time to reach the required number of in-game credits for a new merc or loadout unlock.  To date, the only money I've spent on the game is for trinkets, in-game cosmetics that have no affect on the actual game, and I have more loadouts than I know what to do with.

The game's main mode is Stopwatch.  Two teams, 2-3 objectives, switch sides after the attackers finish or 15 minutes elapse.  The faster team at the end is the winner.  Each of the six maps is quite distinctive: some are long and winding (Dome), others are short and compact (Underground); some involve constant pressure on a moving target (Chapel), others demand just one breakthrough on the part of the attacking team to completely change the pace of the match (Trainyard).  And for those who find themselves wanting just a little CSGO with their DB, there's Execution mode, a pair of 12-round, no-respawn bomb plant maps.  It's a nice change of pace that somehow manages to make the same characters work according to radically different rules (though some might disagree about that).

The characters are colorful, quite distinctive, and manage to be unique without being overpowered.  Each has 1-2 abilities: Skyhammer throws ammo packs and drops an exploding airstrike marker, Aura plants a healing station, Phantom goes invisible, Rhino has a minigun, Fletcher throws remote detonated sticky bombs.  While certain mercs are specialized for combat (e.g. the aptly-named Fragger), everyone can fight and make plays happen outside their main area of expertise.  This isn't Overwatch or TF2; there's a pool of very effective guns and each merc gets two of them, a primary (shotguns, machine guns, SMGs, rifles of various fire rates) and a secondary (pistols of various shapes and sizes), each of which can easily put down the tankiest of opponents with good aim and positioning.  If it all sounds a bit overwhelming, new players can always stick with Skyhammer; he's a versatile merc who can have an impact on any map and at any objective, which makes him perfect for those still unsure what role they prefer.

The biggest issue that DB has is its underdeveloped competitive matchmaker.  While it's improved by leaps and bounds since its introduction, and queue times have gotten shorter (at least during peak hours), games tend to suffer from poor balancing due to the sheer number of unranked players in matches.  I still find it fun, but not everyone will agree.  Even so, those who are liable to get frustrated can have plenty of fun on the standard servers.

In terms of developer support, DB gets pretty regular updates, the most recent of which upped the ante with a competition over which merc would get a special new loadout skin.  They also do a Twitch stream Monday/Wednesday/Friday, which is nice.

All in all, a good game to try for anyone who likes FPS games.

ProsActually free
Satisfying abilities and gunplay with generally good balance
Plenty of variation in characters and maps keeps things fresh and entertaining
The loadout system gives you a meaningful sense of progress without forcing you to pay money

Cons
Competitive matchmaking is hit-or-miss, especially if you're easily frustrated
Characters sometimes get stuck momentarily on corners due to some weird hitbox issues
Execution mode is a bit lean
Final Thoughts

Get it if you like running around in FPS games, racing the clock, and snarky quotes.

Rating (Out of 10): 9

This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

reviewText:
So far it has been enjoyable and has potential to fill the shoes ET/RTCW left behind in the competitive FPS games. The overall gameplay, the fast and smooth movement, fine hitreg, classes and objective play comes together nicely balanced.

In the map design direction, one can feel strong similarities with ET/RTCW! Some areas feel as if they were taken from classic goldrush, supplydepot, oasis, et_ice, etc maps and just re-skinned, while others follow the level design direction what made ET and RTCW the games they were! Multiple paths to primary objectives, sub-objectives, well balanced for both attack and defending teams, many possibilities for defending positions, crossfires and as many strategies much for countering them in the attacks. Truely nice challange for competitive fps players as it's not only about the aimskill but
takes into account all the positioning, moving, predicting, timing and different other mechanics that were equally important in ET & RTCW.

Overall art direction is a bit generic but still nicely done. Simply follows the currently trending modern-styled shooters. The classes all have their own quirks and character and can be told apart from eachother well. Everything looks refined and worked though!

The classes are based largely on ET but with some changes - hard to say yet how good or bad they are. As a key difference you no longer need a specific class (mostly it was the engineer or covert ops in ET/RTCW) to complete the objective. Every class can now repair the tank or plant a bomb. I guess this is the reason why the engineer class has been completly removed, split up and partly replaced by a new class Proxy. She has very fast movement speed and her main ability is planting mines. Can be used in both defending and attacking and maybe even brings the mine-play into more focus than it was in ET.

Medic in general sense is pretty much the same, although there are two of them - one with an area healing item and another one with medpacks. The area healing item seems like a nice change and addition to the gameplay.

As the only use for soldier class was panzerfaust in ET/RTCW, here they've remade it by giving it alot more HP than the other classes have and leaving it as the only class who can use grenades (+also making it a bit slower - each class has slightly different movement speeds). Overall a good change, it can be a fairly strong combination with a medic and already seems to have big use in public games. Covert-ops is replaced by a usual, somewhat useless sniper and has some detection skills instead of stealing of enemy uniform. And the classic fieldop with the airstrikes is pretty much the same old goodness!

Regarding the public matches"
date: the loadout cards system and unlockable characters/rotations sucks balls! In a competitive skill-based game like this you should not have to waste your time on grinding to unlock characters and weapon loadouts. There are way too many loadouts and most of them are totally useless. Also the grinding for them is really time-consuming and in a public mode you don't feel that theres any sense of progression in that area. So makes you question that why the ♥♥♥♥ are they even there? They should be only decorative like in dota or cs for example. The different loadouts are atleast somewhat balanced
recommended: so even in a pay-2-win scenario an experienced played with default items will not be destroyed by a beginner with the best items. In the future in real team matches
hoursPlayed: there should most likely come some mods or rules regarding which loadouts/guns/classses availiable to play with as theres a big need for that.\n\nTL;DR - Dirty bomb used ET/RTCW values to make itself a strong backbone -> has potential to become a next big competitive teamplay fps ."

reviewText:
This game feels like Counter Strike met with Brink then had a baby that was the cousin of Team Fortress 2. For a free game, this is definitely worth a look.

Thing is this baby has an attitude and swag of it's own. Dirty Bomb resembles Counter Strike but moves at a completely different speed and pace. This change in pace is immensely welcomed as I didn't foresee myself becoming immersed in this game. All the basic movements are in the game (minus being able to prone but I don't see why you would need it) and the player is even able to double-triple jump on walls given you go something to rebound off of. If you're going down a hallway that has a lots of overhead room, the player can literally jump wall to wall while dodging and shooting simultaneously. I didn't figure out the game had a feature until I saw another player jumping off the walls (literally)! All the movements are actually quite smooth and of course there is a sprinting and crouch feature.

In addition to great gameplay, Dirty Bomb offers a number of ways to go about your mission. You are given character cards to choose but can only use 3 in a game. My preferred card is a mercenary that uses an automatic weapon. Every character has unique abilities as well. My mercenary can throw a marker to initiate an airstrike. There is a cool-down period but I feel it is has completely appropriate recharge time. Additionally, he can throw ammo to keep your troops in tip top shape. Other classes include sniper that has the ability  to throw a heart beat sensor (to see where enemies are), a medic class that can heal himself in death, heal others in real-time within the vicinity or use his defibrillator on downed allies. The last class I was able to explore (as you have to acquire/unlock/buy other classes) was the shotgun class. This lady has the ability to throw down proximity mines and really ♥♥♥♥ people off. Mines suck only when your the guy walking into them. Some cards have certain upgrades available (through unlocks) and I haven't mentioned the other classes I have no access.

There are a few game modes to choose from. Objective is my personal favorite. Missions are to be completed in three segments. There is always a defending team and an attacking team trying to sabotage something (or steal something). Careful as there is a time limit that needs to be met. Upon dying, you can sometimes re-spawn right away but often times you will have to wait a bit and jump in when the game allows for reinforcements. Stop watch mode allows both teams to attack and defend. Upon successfully attacking, the attacking team will now have to defend their own objective. This game mode is a nice break from objective if you don't like being stuck on defense all the time. Careful! You will have to beat the other teams time! Finally, execution mode consists of 10 rounds of killing off enemies on the opposing team. Alternatively, you can plant a bomb and try to win this way but most cases involve teams killing each other off.

The visuals are very appealing in this game and looking down the iron-sights is one of my favorite properties. The game I feel graphically was well done. Effects from gunshots to explosions were all designed with care. Sounds are neat and definitely suit the game. The narrator in game (updating you on the objective) has an English accent and can be prone to swearing if you're screwing your mission up. Gun shots, explosions and arming C4 are all appropriate and do a good job making the player feel like they are in a battle field.

Overall, a great game and one I would recommend everyone to try. It is FREE, so why not give it a shot!

RATING : 7.4/10

ScreenShots :
This is what an air strike looks like in this game

Dirt and blood with pop up on your HUD

Very peculiar way to arm C4

And the building goes boooooom

reviewText:
A return to the fast paced FPS action of the late 90s and early 2000s. Movement is fluid and fast, reminiscent of games like Quake and Unreal Tournament. The guns are effective and satisfying to use. The classes are pretty good, though since the game is still beta, many haven't been released yet and the ones that are released will probably be tweaked. There are only a handful of maps right now, but they're all fairly well designed.

It's a bit grindy to earn credits for mercs and their loadouts, but everything can be earned through gameplay instead of having to pay real money. Can't really complain too much for a free game. I love that it feels like an oldschool fast FPS instead of the slow, plodding, movement-restricted FPS games of the modern era.

My biggest gripe is there's no option to pay $30ish bucks to unlock all mercs/loadouts. I wish this was a real retail release instead of a grindy unlock game. Otherwise it's great, give it a try!

reviewText:
Making a new Review of the game since it's been release, had a preview from the beta but since that one is out of date alot I thought I'd make a new one.


Do I recommend this game? Yes. Absolutely. No doubt. I'd rate it 8/10 at this point, probobly one of the best F2P games today and ever released. Pretty much what BRINK should have been but with a bit less parkour then in that game. With time it might get to be a 9/10+ game.

Why? Well since I did play in the late Alpha and earlie Beta stage I have seen how much this game has grown. I dont know how often the interface/menu system has been changed but for now I really think it works better then ever. The classes have been tunned alot since Alpha to make them more balanced.

Now some might wonder why I dont have more hours to the game then I have, well I dont know to be honest... played it alot when it came to steam (most of the hours) then I kinda stoped when I started playing D3. Comming back to the game I really dont know why I stoped.. the game is great, runs well even if it could do with some more optimization when listening to some friends who have a worse comp then me. Running 2500k i5 @ 4.5ghz, R9 280X and 16gb ram at the moment, and for me it's running flawlessly.

Biggest thing I didnt like before about Dirty Bomb was the fact that it took ages to get Credit's in the game since you barely got any from finishing the matches and you had only 3 daily quests a day pretty much. Now when I've come back the match Credit's are pretty much the same but the daily quests have changed to having 3 quests ever 2 hour cycle. Now this is great since now you can get like 10k credit's a day if you want litteraly, with booster it would be even more.

So feeling like you have to pay for the game to be able to get a class now is completely gone and it is well made at the moment since you dont get that pay2win" feeling when it would have taken a month before to get just one class. Prices from real money I guess aint much to talk about considering the game is free and to support the game development and future updates we'll have to pay something!


How is the gameplay then? Very fun in my opinion

reviewText:
EDIT: A developer has commented on this review, stating that several of the problems I describe have been addressed. While this review remains an accurate description of my experience with Dirty Bomb up to August 2015, I intend to re-install Dirty Bomb and play it again in the near future. After that happens, I will update this review with additional thoughts and impressions.

Dirty Bomb is a lot of fun to play, with great weapons and versatile character classes. But it is sorely lacking in several departments.

+ Guns & mercs. Plenty of variety. Each merc is a unique way to play.
+ Stable. Game has never once crashed on me
+ Colorful. Still uses DX9, but graphics look great.
+ Level design is great. Lots of different ways to attack a given position.
+ Gameplay is quick. Completing a mission with a good team is very satisfying.

- Only five maps and two modes.
- Missions are linear. The stages never change.
- The rumor about Dirty Bomb is that it is pay to win. It is not. HOWEVER: if you want to play with more than the three default mercenaries, and the merc you want is not in free rotation" (playable for free for a limited time)

reviewText:
I can't reccomend this game.

It's just another FPS that's pushed as being competitive or a prospective esport and yet the developers seemed to miss the point completely.

Ok, the shooting, movement and overall gunplay seems to actually be okay. There's not really as much of a skill ceilling as W:ET in regards to the movement but there is something interesting going on. I couldn't really put my finger on it though, there's some nifty things you can do with walljumps but it's certainly not intended.

What kills this game from the get go is the business model. It's free to play. Sadly, there's some cool abilities, guns and tools but they are spread over so many classes and there just isn't any reason to play many of them. It's also pretty ridiculous that they expect the game to ever have a thriving competitive scene when they expect you to either pay up or grind for almost every single class.

I played the game a lot before it came to steam when everything was unlocked for everybody and the loadouts didn't exist. It was much better then but it still suffered from almost all the classes being useless. Bushwacker was so OP, it was insane. Speaking to other players, apperently Pyro was too. They made the other classes feel like wet paper, simply because of the guns. Whether this is still true, I am not sure, I only got to play a couple of the classes but the limitations on classes and loadouts hurts this game so badly that it's not even worth talking about anything else.

If you are looking for another competitive FPS game to play, you won't find it here. There's loads of potential for a really good game but as long as it continues to have content locked out from players then a scene will never grow. Could have been good, but it isn't.

EDIT: So I continued to play to inform myself more and perhaps highlight some of the other issues with the game.

The guns are so badly balanced it makes my eyes water. ADS is practically useless on pretty much everything, due to the fact that the animations for recoil will block your vision of the already bad iron sights.

Rifles seem to suffer the most due to the recoil they have. You can easily outgun someone with the proxy secondary, an SMG, at long ranges. The same goes for the smaller pistols too. The recoil spread is so tight and the classes move so fast that you can actually outgun people using rifles at long ranges.

The developers also don't beat around the bush in being open about the fact that loadouts for your classes are simply better than others. Using a tier list that ranges from iron to gold (+obsidian), the better the tier the more augments" the loadout will have. Meaning someone using a gold load out vs a default one will be at a significant advantage one way or another.

The whole game is designed to be a F2P time sink."

reviewText: Dirty Bomb is a free-to-play FPS, heavily revolving teamwork. It has around 12 classes (some must be bought), that all have their own weapons, leveling up systems (card-based), and skills. This game is amazing. It has a lot of strategy incorporated to make it an all around team-based game. Whether playing alone, or with a couple of friends, Dirty Bomb delivers on the FPS market that has lost its spark. For only $22 you can get the starter pack, which unlocks five permanent Mercs (classes) and grants you around 50,000 credits (which are normally pretty difficult to get), so if you have the money, make sure to get that as well, if not, enjoy the game anyway! It's a lot of fun, and they switch up temporary Mercs that are unlocked so you always have someone or something new to play with. Leveling up cards from bronze to gold or higher is addicting, and takes time, but is satisfying when done after hard work. Dirty Bomb also has daily challenges to help get credits and XP, sometimes with double XP events. Try it out, it's a blast!

reviewText: This is easily the best FPS I've played in quite some time.  FPS games that are all carbon copies of each other and controller friendly" is the order of the day these days.  But not this game.  If you attempt to pull the three shots to the nuts that people pull in Call of Duty
date:
Battlefiled and the other copy/paste war games you will do quite horribly in this game.  This game is very much like Return to Castle Wolfenstein/Enemey Territory (and made by the company who created ET) with character unlocks that works similar to League of Legends.  So far it's been quite good for a beta and I've dropped almost 40 hours into it over two different weekends when the beta was live.

You will enjoy this game if you like:
1.  A game where aim matters and shooting for heads is required to excel
2.  A game built with mouse/keyboard in mind and doesn't have a "press this button to do a cool animation"
3.  A game where movement is just as important as aim.  You can jump off walls to reach new areas.  Yup
recommended:
it's awesome
4.  Class based team combat with "Mercs" to unlock LoL-style
5.  Multiple objectives per map to complete on offense before you then switch to defense and hold those objectives
6.  5v5 ranked system at launch

You will hate this game if you:
1.  Enjoy proning.  Seriously
hoursPlayed:
F every single one of you guys
2.  Enjoy unloading a magazine in 1.5 seconds and hitting a guy in the nuts with 3 of those sprayed bullets across the map with your SMG for the kill
3.  Enjoy only shooting people and dislike objectives beyond shooting people
4.  Do not like jumping in videogames
5.  Hate skillful movement beyond "running lanes".  If you want to only press forward to move then this is not the game for you

So far I would recommend it.  It's going to be free to play when it's released and as long as the devs avoid any of the more notorious free to play strategies then I'll support it.

The next beta will be soon :)"

reviewText: This game was a genuinely enjoyable spiritual successor to Wolfenstein Enemy Territory. Sure its F2P, but it wasn't P2W, at least until the introduction of Phantom. Phantom is borderline invisible, has a mêlée attack thats one hit kill for most mercs, is able to move like something out of the f**king Matrix, has a shield, and a SMG. The games balance was always a bit wonky, but now its about as well balanced as a raft in a Tsunami. I dread to think how unplayable the game will get when Phantom goes into free rotation. DB was a fun game but as it stands right now tho I can't recommend DB with Phantom in it.

reviewText:
As much as I would like to recommend this game, the balancing for characters is too poor to even consider it.

On one hand you have the Nader who has very powerful skills and a grenade launcher that will dominate the competition.

Then you have characters like Proxy who can plant, repair, and defuse very quickly, but has very little life and weapons that will almost never kill another player if you charge in headlong or sneak up on them.

Don't even get me started on Phantom.

This game has a competetive mode, but I don't want to go into it because I know that it will be filled with just Phantom. A competetive mode is supposed to test pure player skill, not just be dominated by someone with very little skill, but they chose a certain character and can now make it to the highest rank in the game.

Balance the characters, and this game will be great. I already have had a lot of fun playing it, but the character balancing has forced me to leave several matches because I wasn't having fun.












Phantom is OP plz nerf

reviewText:
This game. Oh no. The concept is good, and the gameplay is alright, but thats it. The characters arent balanced at all, the game has a brutal paywall, and an evil RNG system.

The Gameplay:

This is the only part of the game that is currently decent, and may be enough for some people to continue playing this game. The mechanics are like a combination of Team Fortress 2 and Call of Duty. There are several different classes which all have special abilities such as calling in airstrikes, reviving teammates, and throwing grenades.

The movement is very fast, there is some level of parkour, and this game could definitely become competitive at some point. Using hipfire rather than aiming down sights is generally more effective.

The teamwork area of this game is currently entirely lacking. Though that cant be fixed, certain mechanics can reinforce it a bit more.

Character Balance:

There is no real change in playstyle from character to character..
Which is to say that it is near meaningless to play one class over another, and thats not balance, thats lack of development.
The new Phantom character is ridiculously overpowered, and can easily kill someone without them having any chance to retaliate, even from directly in front of them, as has happened to me.

The Paywall:

This game screams for you to waste your money. To get new characters you need to save up from 30-50 thousand credits, and then you have to get a card to use him anyway which will be a minimum of 1000 credits, if you happen to get him in the first spin, which is unlikely considering the wealth of hardly different characters.

Of course, you can directly buy these characters for 7-10 dollars, which is ridiculously expensive for a single character, and even then you still need another card as a loadout to use the character.

And of course, there is a way to double the amount of credits you earn, which costs even more money. The average game after daily bonuses will give you around 600 on a win and 180 on a loss, from my experience.

And then the RNG:

This. Is the worst thing that exists in any game. This is how you get loadout cards for your characters, and the odds are stupidly low to obtain anything worthwhile. So steep that you have an 85% chance to get the lowest tier card! But of course this is solved by selling 'elite cases' which guarantee you a higher tier card.

All these systems combine to make an extremely Pay to Win game which, though the gameplay can be enjoyable, is thoroughly flawed.

And if you think its not pay to win, just remember that they made it such a grind so that you would be pressured to pay. Why else?


Give it a try, dont waste your money.

reviewText:
Game has serious balance issues as the devs/company in control seem to be focusing more on creating lots of classes (mercs) and not about game design. Power creep is a massive issue in this game and it's still extremely young.

Ignoring all of the claims to P2W, I would still hesitate to pick this game up as although <lvl5 lobbies are good for new players, normal servers are a cluster♥♥♥♥ of being steamrolled by those who have played the game for a significant time and hence have access to a wider range of classes. As such the more experienced players can change their tactics to suit the way the game is playing out i.e enemy team is camping -> explosive classes, enemy team is rushing -> defensive classes; whereas newer players are stuck to a handful of classes (which are dictated by the weekly rotation).

If you want a mindless CS/TF2/BF crossover shooter and don't care about winning or KDA, this game is extremely fun. However from a competetive standpoint the maps, weapons and classes are extremely imbalanced (and the devs have made no progress to show this will ever change).

reviewText:
I have been gaming since Doom and along the way there have only been a hand full of games that give me this satisfied feeling.  This is my first written review of a game on steam because I believe this game deserves your attention. I have missed the feeling of twitched based arena shooters such as Quake 3 arena and team arena. There have been some games who have tried to recapture that feeling but nothing so far has been able to hook me until Dirty Bomb.

There are some glaring problems such as a bad anti cheat. Hackers will come in waves and they will infest the competitive match making scene making it difficult to recommend trying that mode to new players. Bugs are present that have been around for a long time and it seems each new patch breaks something else and you wont see a fix for it for several weeks. I feel as if the developers don't value the customers as much as some other companies do, for example Grinding Gear Games.

If you enjoy really fast paced twitch shooters with plenty of competition then you can't go wrong with Dirty Bomb.

reviewText:
So Dirty Bomb...how can I sum this game up into words...

First off, this game is fun. It truelly is. The gameplay is probably one of the best aspects about DB. When you have a good team, you can get some pretty interesting matches. There isn't many objective based FPS games anymore so its a nice change from the norm right now. HOWEVER, this game has a LOT of issues that can't be simply ignored.

Problem 1: The payment system for this game is a real downer. Seriously, I'm all for grinding to unlock characters and its ment to make you keep playing. I understand this and I'm okay with games doing that if you dont wanna spend real money. Dirty Bomb takes it to far, each game you earn around 200-500 in game credits. Not bad you'd think but characters cost around 30k to 50k to unlock. Thats a LOT of games to just unlock one character and it'd most likely get a little tedious and boring after so long. However, if you truely want a character you can skip all that grinding to purchase a character with real money! For around 10.99. Thats right, 10.99 for just one person.

Problem 2: There is a pretty clean unblanace of classes in this game. Some of you may argue, Naw man

reviewText: Dirty Bomb is a free-to-play, basic First Person Shooter, slash Multiplayer Online Battle Arena. You play as one of three types, A Soldier, Healer, or Engineer, in PVP teams with other players. It is fairly straight-forward and there is very little learning curve from playing the tutorial. The visuals aren't bad, what you would expect of a modern day FPS, and the queue times are not long for PVP. The game doesn't really stand out, as it is strictly about PVP with little story behind it. I recommend giving it a try since it is free-to-play, but if you are looking for something substantial, you can probably do better elsewhere.

reviewText: Needs a ton of work, no in game way to report hacking, which is rampant in this game. Repetitive missions that get old very quickly, the classes have zero balance, and with the way the mission are objective based the cooldowns can cripple a team. Overall its fun for a day, but not really a fun shooter after that. All in all, this is a hackers paradise, you have 5 or 6 steps to report anyone, and a nexon account is required to do so. Big thumbs down, not really pay to win, but you can sort of see it going that way in the near future. It quickly sours into a poor experience.
