reviewText: TL,DR version : A free but unfinished team-based" (and that is being generous) pay-to-win game with unbalanced everything trying to rewrite the success of  Team Fortress 2. Don't bother with it for now. Stick to TF2.\n\nI tried to appreciate this game after getting an invite to the closed beta
date: I really did. But after 2 hours
recommended: I gave up. I saw everything I needed to see.\n\nHere is a nice list of what I saw as broken in this game : a few limited maps with 2 modes only (they were still testing maps)
hoursPlayed: 65% of servers empty (wasted resources) and half of those with players are in the EU (at the time of writing this : 70 servers
voteText: 24 with players and 15 of those are from the EU).\n\nHalf the "classes" (mercs) are behind a paywall. Saw 8 mercs total (for now)
helpfulPercent: 2 mercs are on free rotation and 2 are provided at the start thus limiting replayability quickly (compared to 9 free classes on tf2 and none locked). I did see on the wiki that there are more out there... I can presume they are limiting the amount of available mercs for the closed beta. You can buy the other mecs with real cash or ingame credits. You gain credits by playing matches (smallish amount) or through the quests system. Do this x amount of times and get y creds.  An excellent idea overall but playing a long time to unlock a single character priced at around 50k or paying 7 to 12$ makes it obvious where the deal is.\n\nNo incensitives to play as a team. All the big rewards are in the k/d ratio... So what is the point of objectives if killing the enemy team is worth more than destroying or defending the objectives? Helping your teammates gives out little exp but fatally feeding slugs to your opponent gives you more? That is the complete opposite of a team-based system. As a side note
votesHelpful: I noticed that the deathmatch or team deathmatch modes are curiously absent. With the current system
votesTotal:
that mode would be quite popular.

Now the kicker : unbalanced classes. This game uses a card system where your merc will have special abilities based upon what is on the card : from lead to obsidian. Lead is a basic card while higher cards with increased value gain augments to increase that specific merc's abilities. Thus a player using a merc with a gold card has x3 more advantages over a player with a lead card. And guess what do you have at the start? Ouch!

To remedy this
votesFunny: I did notice that there are servers that are for players underneath a certain level threshold. This would
commentsCount: in theory
column16: give new players a chance to get to know the game properly while fighting players of equal skills. Unfortunaltely
column17: instead of pushing those new players on those servers (which were all empty at the time I checked)
column18: they move them on regular servers with players that managed to gain higher cards. A simple fix would be an automated system to push the new players in those appropriate servers and having them filled with bots if the player base is too low. Even playing vs bots is better than being destroyed (thus leading to salty rage quits) unfairly.\n\nFinally
column19: I did get a good laugh at times. For example a message saying I just gained 1xp for being in a group would sporadically apprear. YES I am validated to play in a team! Also the tutorial mentionned a Rule #3 for the game : Don't be a ♥♥♥♥. Wish there was a way to force players to go back to the training level so they can review that rule again and again. reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is one of the best Free to Play Games I have ever played, and it is the best FPS Game so far. This game is still in beta, so this review is in no way complete. I will try to make this review as unbiased as I can.

A lot of the Nay-sayers either think it is pay2win (NEWSFLASH: It's not...), or they left because of hackers (every damn game has hackers. Nexon and Splash Damage have significantly fixed their anti cheat system. Hackers are few and far between), or they haven't gotten good at the game (get good scrubs), or haven't played enough (you need at least 15 hours to be allowed to review. Steam should have this rule in place)

Pros:
- Fast Paced, Action packed Gameplay
- Many Characters (Mercs) to Choose from
- Free rotation of paid characters
- Objective-based gameplay (Execution coming-soon)
- Harsh gameplay (if you die... too bad for you)
- Teamwork oriented (You can't run off and be a Hero")
- Unique abilities for every Merc
- Forces you to take advantage of the game mechanics (Hip firing is key... unless you are sniping)
- Gives you an incentive to keep playing  (Dialy missions)
- Skill-based (in no way Pay to Win)

Cons:
- Expensive Mercs ($5.99 - $9.99)
date: however all characters are unlockable with ingame money (30
hoursPlayed: 000 c) which takes time to collect\n- Hackers (***EDIT: They have improved the Anti-Cheat System a lot since I wrote this review.) you find them quite a bit and they are a pain in the ♥♥♥
voteText:
although you could switch servers.
- Balancing. Many times I have found myself overpowered by a team of level 35+ players when my team is full of sub level 10's

Suggestions:
- Add more variety to daily missions (Defuse 10 C4s

votesTotal: Get 15 headshots
votesFunny:
etc.) The same missions over and over again gets boring really fast.
- Improve game balance.

This Game has a lot of potential. It is still in Beta
commentsCount:
so the cons could well be fixed by the full version.

TL;DR: Really Good Game. Needs some fixing. You should play. NOW!

reviewText:
If you're a fan of fast paced FPS games you need to give Dirty Bomb a try..

It's by the same developer as the very well regarded Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory, and takes the form of a team-based rolling-objective high-speed high-accuracy shooter. I like to think of it as TF2 meets Quake3 in London with wall-jumping...

Much has been made - and misunderstood - about how the game monetises itself (it's F2P afterall). I'm happy to say the game allows you to compete on a level playing field with people investing money - there's certainly no special ammo or pay-only weapons or things like that.

If you do intend to pay for most of your progress with in-game-earned Credits try to maximise the Missions you are set - they can be worth significant amounts to you.

I’m a fan of their art and general style too – it’s British without being hackneyed or irritating, and there are some lovely touches of quintessentially dry humour. What’s more the character design is great. There are both male and female characters but none pander to the dull, well-trodden path of buxom ladies and rippling torso’d men. The design feels more cohesive, solid and more believeable as a result. I find it great.

I'm not going to say the game is perfect - I'm sure the developers would be the first to agree - but they are very open with their work and stream 4 times a week across 2 twitch channels. They take questions and answer them in a manner that's honestly refreshing compared to many other devs.

If I had to criticize - I’d say the real-money cost of many of the items seems too high. Especially the Mercs (characters / hereos / etc.) - this honestly pushes me towards the F2P route to unlock them.

Summing up :: This is my go-to game at the moment and I'm having a lot of fun. If you like a fast FPS experience I can certainly recommend you give it a try.

(If you want to know more - I have YT videos in my profile with more detailed looks into the monetisation system of Dirty Bomb, Tips & Tricks for new players, etc.)

reviewText:
Impressions from a RTCW and W:ET fanatic written with the same audience in mind.

Last time I played Dirty bomb, was about a year ago. I soon gave up though only to return now and see how it evolved over the months. Always keep in mind that it is still in Beta. This is my opinion and it doesn't mean it is objective.

Also, it is a bit unfair to compare it with W:ET + ETpro which optimised the gameplay even more.

Dirty bomb is and feels a hybrid between Brink and W:ET:

Graphics: The game is kind of demanding if you want to play it on high settings. The art design is similar to brink. I won't say a lot about it since you can watch streams and videos to see how it looks.

I will focus on the fact that the classes (mercs) are not very distinguishable while I prersonally feel they are a bit dark. E.g.: im not always sure who is the medic (there are 3 types of them). The menus, hud etc are clean and neat, while it has alot of graphics customization.

Map design is interesting, but nowhere near rtcw_beach or goldrush. All in all, I would prefer cleaner graphics and easier to the eye with less bells".

Gameplay:
Differences:

-The game has 15 classes of which you choose the 3 you want to "carry" to the server. Each class can be customised a bit more. Also
date: each class has 2-3 unique abilities (just like in ET
hoursPlayed: eng has mines etc.).\n\n-Some classes run faster than other and the sprint is faster than this of ET and RTCW. There is no sprint bar. What I miss is that you cannot Sprint + A or D
voteText:
so you can't make the crazy jukes from ET to the same extend.

- There is self heal after a certain amount of time you take no damage.
- Medic packs: You take one and that's it
helpfulPercent:
you start regenerating fast.
- Forget leaning left right.
- Iron sights
- Forget bunny-hopping
- As of now
votesHelpful:
max fov is 100

Similarities:
- Gunfights are exciting and you are very bullet spongy (even for headshots).
- Voice chat remains almost intact. V57
- Objectives and gametypes are similar to RTCW and ET

Audio:
Voice commands and gunsounds have to be improved. Unfortunately there is no oomph in the sounds of the guns.

Conclusion: It is worth giving it a shot when it comes out. While there is plenty of room for improvement I have a feeling that it will offer something new to the FPS scene. Will it take off? No one really knows. It really depends if they will make it pay-2-win when it hits the market.

Let's hope it will get to be the next W:ET :)."

reviewText:
This game suffers from the same problems all games of this type do. Generous respawning mechanics create an endless back-and-forth that is unimaginably unfun, especially on such a small scale. Initially I was hoping for something a bit more like Counter-Strike, but instead I was reminded of TF2 with everything charming stripped away and replaced with a generic artstyle and gameplay that invoked CoD more than Enemy Territory. It tries to be fast-paced, but works against itself by making the game feel more like a deathmatch.


TL;DR: just play tf2 if you want an F2P objective+class based FPS. frankly, it's a superior game in every department. this game offers nothing new in it's current state and I can't see the core of the game changing much over the course of development.

P.S. the monetization model in this game is a joke. it incorporates every greedy, scummy microtransaction on earth and locks everything behind an insurmountable grindwall. do not bother with this game unless you are a wallet warrior.

reviewText:
Dirty Bombs deep down is a team based shooter with the full intention of relying on multiple classes and cooperation in order to achieve goals for each mission. However, in its current form the game seems to focus more on needing the same 1-2 classes in order to win consistently. Character classes (mercs) are currently poorly balanced and a look through the discussion forums indicates the company developing Dirty Bombs doesn't have balancing classes out as a top priority. That's pretty arrogant and foolish if this is indeed true. Recently I played 3 rounds where the opposing team played one class and easily demolished the opposing team due to overpowered abilities. Also, all 3 of those rounds were on different servers with different players. The fun of the game quickly dissipated (although the first couple days I had it before the recent patch update it was a fairly enjoyable experience) and many of us who downloaded and spent money on perks are already looking to move away from this and onto something else.

There's a lot of complaints of Dirty Bombs being a 'pay to win game' and currently there seems to be some validation to those complaints. Now as I write this Dirty Bombs is in Beta Testing and therefore could be better balanced by the time it is completed, but then I would STRONGLY recommend waiting for this to be a finished product before jumping into it.

Overall Dirty Bombs has the right heart in what it wants to be, but overpowering issues, weak level design, a growing 'pay to win' reputation, and just isn't fun with the latest merc updates. I recommend taking the wait and see." Don't be in a hurry folks. It's always better to wait.

Grade: C-"

reviewText:
I've not played as much of the game as some, and I've sure as hell not bought anything, as I don't think I ever will for a free-to-play game.
Yet, with those in mind, I'll say with as much humility as I possibly can that I frequently dominate the leaderboards in games (that aren't stopwatch, I'm not Korean.)
How could that be? A free-to-play game must mean it is pay-to-win, certainly!
For this game, such is not the case. The only purchase that can be made is that of either characters (which can ALL be purchased with in-game currency) or a higher chance for a better loadout, which do not actually improve quality.
You see, the highest quality loadout one can get (in terms of actual, direct benefits) is that of bronze. There are higher tiers, but they change nothing.

With the business model complaints out of the way, I'll say this: Dirty Bomb is one of my favorite competitive games as of right now.
With blazing movement speed; simple to use, but hard to master parkour; and characters that are all varied and have different pros and cons, despite some similarity; this game is more addictive than crack cocaine. If you've ever played Brink (which, incidentally, was made by the same people), then it is similar to that, but with much more clarity for telling who is on who's team and much more of a competitive focus. The guns feel good to fire, the melee is an entirely viable combat tactic, and working with your team makes you virtually unstoppable. While there are certainly a few issues with balance, and there aren't many maps, what is there is insanely fun to play and makes for a wonderful team game to play.

TL;DR It's basically if Team Fortress 2 ♥♥♥♥ed Counter-Strike in the ♥♥♥ with a syringe filled with steroids. Play it now.

reviewText:
TL;DR: I recommend, great game overall pretty good balanced with a few hiccups. Tremendously fair F2P model, 0 P2W at all. Explosionspammy at times. Very few competitve players (yet)




Dirty Bomb is a FPS focused around teamwork and playing the role of your merc (playable character). If you keep that in mind, all classes are balanced, while some perform a bit underwhelming.  Medics get lower HP the better they can heal, Damagedealer have high HP and explosives yet no utility, supporter/engineers have a mix between low and medium HP, while being overall versatile.

GUNS
The guns in the game all have there respective range in which they shine. Shotguns and sniperrifles being the hardest to use due to the high movementspeed of most characters. Models itself are nice. Have some neat details. Sound of the guns is okay, could feel a bit more powerful for some weapons. Just the arsenal of firearms itself is mediocre. Shotguns all feel pretty much the same, same for sniper rifles. SMGs and Assault rifles are very shooter standard.

MOVEMENT
Movement. This is DBs biggest distinctive mark to stand out of the mass of shooters. First of all the gameplay is pretty fast, hipfire accuracy is very good. Time to kill overall decently high. That results in exciting firefights where good aiming gets rewarded a lot. On top of that the game has so called double jumps that make you bounce of any wall. Results are a lot more movement options, and shortcuts on the maps. Some jumps are quite tricky, giving you a higher skillceiling. (The maps have different spots made on purpose for doublejumps, while some other spots seem to be found by the community)

MERCS
Characters all have a distinct look and role. Every character has one or two special abilities, like a turret, medkits, a healing station, mines or a much faster repairtool. Nothing we never saw before, but the choice is big (21 mercs currently) and you have to nail it down to 3 per match. Most mercs are locked, with 3 being free for everyone in a 2weekly rotation. New ones can be bought with either ingamecredits (1-2 weeks playing per char when playing 1-2 hours daily. Can be shorter if you time your playtime with the missions for more credits) or for real munies. (Which is a lot, and I wouldnt do, unless you want to support the devs) Callouts from each merc are by a different voiceactor, with different phrase. I like it a lot.
Some mercs are more powerful then others, but currently no merc is ridiculous  better then the rest of its class. Some feel a bit weak, but its early access, and many weak spots got touched already.
Guns for mercs cant be simply choosen, you rather euqip loadout cards that define primary, secondary and minor skills. Loadoutcards come in different varations and colors, while ALL gameplay affecting loadout options are buyable for credits, only COSMETIC stuff is available at a siginifcantly higher chance for real money.
What I heavily dislike is the amount of explosionspam going on in public matches. Way to many nades, bombs and mines of all sort and size...

MAPS+gamemodes
Maps get designed for exactly one (in theory 2) gamemodes. The main is a Rush alike with different stages and objectives to reach. Either only one round, or each site per team. The 2nd is a CS defuse clone. 1 bomb. 2 bombspots. no respawns. 2 minutes time.
That results in different well designed maps with a few really difficult chokepoints, that heavily put defenders in a advantage. Overall appearance of each map is okay. Many yellow tubes and yellow colored parts defining the dirty bomb look, while overall each map has a different and fitting colorstyle. Not as colorful as CoD though.

Performance and Menu:
Menus are clunky and sometimes dont react, I would like it more snappy there. Setting options are enough to make the game work on most PCs. Overall performance ingame is really smooth. No laggs and only rare spikes on my end. (Which was a lot worse in the beginning)
++++the game has russian servers. If youre EU player and you ever played CS, you know why thats great. WAY less language barriers ingame.

Basically, this gae needs to revamp the VAC, cut ot hackers, initiate a bot mode, tweak the abilities a bit ( Nader this week is a bit too OP ), maybe even seperate the maps and objectives into several missions ( Demonstrated in TF2's Soldier training ). It needs a lot of improvement, because if there is none, it will not last long.

reviewText:
I started playing this game with little to no expectation, strangely I found myself quite addicted to it. I'll try to be fair as possible but still of course, it's biased as it's personal opinion afterall.


Few reasons I suppose I'll list as Pros.

Pros:

- Fast paced and fun FPS with interesting mechanics; give some reminecent and nostalgia to the older FPS of the 90s yet still have a bit of a modern fps feel.
- FREE TO PLAY, I spent zero $ to get anything I need and no reason you shouldn't either if you so choose so. If you like the game you'll eventually get in the game currency to buy your mercs and create card/load outs naturally as you just simply play the game because you enjoy it. There is no reason one should complain about how slow one unlocks content or how expensive some things are, those are ultra first world problems should be completely omitted.
- Most of the mercenaries I've played so far provide some good fun individually and can all exploit different gameplay or map mechanics to a general level or even specific specialized map/character mechanic/behavior.
- A good number of differently load out/guns/combination of cards per individual merc.
- Good games are quite rewarding, a good game in my opinion is everyone under stands their roles and play them well or even as just intended regardless win or lose.  Everything and every mercenary can make a difference if played well/accordingly.  Following points below ------v
*KDR means something: Some mercs are better than others are killing/denying enemy of objectives and zoning
*Objectives means something: Some mercs are better than others are getting the objective done while those who are denying/killing/zoning are doing their jobs to keep these objective mercs safe
*Dying means something: You can time your deaths to cause disruption to the enemy team if you're skilled enough and die right when the counter is ready to spawn you. Other than that, if you are dead, you provide no purpose while counting down to revive and spending extra time running across the map.
*In the end, the game is meant to be a team oriented piece.
*You can massacre people but no one doing objectives will do no good. People doing objectives but everyone dying will also do no good. Balance of both is key but will only happen in a good" game or if you got a solid team of friends with you willing to progress further/learn.
- There so far isn't exactly a "useless" mercenary or "OP" those would all be opinions only no factual evidence. Every merc does well at somethings and bad at others.
- Easy to pick up with even more skill set to gain with gameplay

Cons:

- A decent quantity of toxic players and no way to mute chat (you can mute mic but not chat) (can be quite prevalent and really really bad depending on individual basis and "rng") with all the same type of personality; especially certain pub nub scrub demographics. That's not to say there are also decent-good people types playing this game but those salt and sour players energy vampires really get irritating if it's happening continuously.  The toxic levels seem a bit more prevalent than other f2p games for some reason but thus the internet in general...
- You may say
date: why not just stick with comp?\n*Long game searches\n*If you do run into a hacker in one
recommended: game is officially ruined.\n*Quite possible to get people on your team who quit prematurely and ruin the game. Even when it says "safe to leave" I don't think it is and still penalizes you...\n*Can turn out imbalanced as hell somewhat often
hoursPlayed: reason I'm guessing is lack of player base there.\nActual reason
voteText: I do not know. For example: you can be on a team total of level 3x whereas the other team can be 6x. If theoretically all 10 players are the same skill level
helpfulPercent: those on the higher side should have map and mechanical knowledge at their disposal more so than the lower level team. So many factors\n- A few hackers here and there but it's only really bad if you end up with them in a competitive match since you can just leave a regular pub any time. This can tie into the above mention as it's easy to blame players for hacks regardless of skill level or if they are or not if someone deems some (impossible chit is happening so they must be hacking).\n- Some load outs may seem useless
votesHelpful:
you can gamble unwanted cards from lead-cobalt but there is no way to downgrade if you'd want to do so.

As for PC optimization

reviewText:
For now, I have to say, I don't want to recommend this game. The game itself is good, but they have a rootkit anti cheat program.

The gameplay has a lovely system, you start with two unlocked mercenaries, and temp unlocked ones. You earn in game currency by playing, and finishing quests. There are level up boosts, this can be boxes to unlock gear for a character, or a money boost.
This is an objective based game, each merc(Class) has different strengths and weaknesses.

I do truly enjoy it, but the anti cheat program makes it difficult to play.  You can't use process hacker (A replacement program for your task manager) and many others. You have to not even have it installed. Or change the file directory name to something without hacker" in it. If you log in too many times still trying to figure out how to keep the game from kicking you out for a third party program. You will get a temp ban of two days... which is wrong. reviewText:
First, on the good side of the game:
1) visuals are good for a dx9 game.
2) music and sounds are good. I liked it.
3) you can always find a good server to play.
4) interactive gameplay.
5) double and even triple jumps!
6) quick actions


bad parts:
1) This game is fun at first run but boring in long term.
2) It tries to be many games yet it wants to stay original. and the result is eh" game.
3) Spawns are stupid. there is a lot of spawn kills in every single game.
4) map layout is stupid. there is a lot of death lanes/halls in game
5) HP regeneration is stupid.
6) cpu optimization is bad.
7) Do you use the hit register *ding* sound in TF2? This game have it but it *ding*s as the client side and not server side so it's pretty much useless.
8) characters are boring. I don't know if it's trying to be different or be unique but it fails at both.

I was really looking forward for the competitive game mode but I was bored as hell trying to level up.
Hopefully it's a beta and with a little work from the dev it will be a good game. but for now it's a time killing game."

reviewText:
I love this game, I have played the 12.5 hours on my account in the last 24 hours.

The game has come a long way from the first time I played it over a year ago (I think it was closer to two years, as I believe I played it to take a break from Titanfall.).

The gunplay is satisfying, and fun. The sounds for the most part feel substantial and the movement feels fluid.

The graphics are good enough, and the characters are all unique enough that each person can find someone that they like.

The microtransactions do not feel required at all. That being said this review is written mere hours away from my plan to purchase the starter DLC on steam. I though tI was enjoying this game enough to support the developers.

But I can't.

Installation was simple, but launching the game itself seemed to be problematic. The Anti-cheat software used by Nexon told me I had unapproved software on my computer. I turned everything I have off. Leaving only Mumble, Steam, and Dirty Bomb running. Still flagged as having unapproved software. I decided to update my catalyst labs software for my GPU, still flagged. I next tried to update my razer and logitech software.

SUCCESS!

I get to play. Queue montage of me sucking at Dirty Bomb for the next day.

Today I finish a match and as soon as I type GG, I get a plain grey screen with the notice that my account has been banned for two day for using unapproved software.

Seriously.

More google searches will show that the Anti-cheat being used in this game constantly gives false positives, and there is even a thread on Nexon's forums that asks you to submit a list of software that causes the false positives.

For me this is a deal breaker, I love this game, but the Anti-cheat is enough to keep me away, and encourage no one else to play it either. If you give it a try, do try to avoid getting attached to it. I would play for a week or two before spending any money to make sure that you are not flagged falsely.

reviewText:
This game is currently in the beta build, so a lot of my problems with it might be fixed.

Okay, so this game is pretty decent. For a F2P game, it's one of the best out there. It's fast, competartive, and fairly intuative. I'm not too wordy, so I'll just list my pros and cons.

Pros:
- Fun game play
- Short matches
- Unique characters and classes
- Interesting load out mechanic that is extreemly unique
- Doesn't appear to be too many trolls, which is nice for a F2P shooter

Cons:
- Matches are nearly impossible to join with friends. Servers are always saying that they are full when they aren't, or aren't full when they are.
- Guns feel like airsoft guns. With the exception of the mounted machine guns, they all sound weak and pitiful. Even the not!Deagle sounds like something that would barely cause welts.
- As it stands, the game isnt terribly balanced. Shotguns are too powerful at close ranges (even for shotguns), rifles are too weak, and medics can heal themselves way too well, making them the best people for a firefight, which is kind of silly.

All in all, a very solid F2P game.

reviewText:
First of all, its a fun game, no doubts about that.

But it has a huge ammount of issues, no matter what you say and try to argue about, its an fps game, meaning skill comes first, and in this game there isn't that, guns barely do any damage, headshot means nothing here.. Knifes do more damage than rifles for some odd reasons and the objectives feel lackluster.

So, lets see the pros and cons.

Pros:

-Fun
-Something different
-Lot's of mercs/classes
-Good style of graphics (They really look pretty)

Cons:
-Gunplay feels stupid and random
-Matches feel too one-sided with no chance of one player making a difference or even having the power
-Extremely low skill cap
-Mercs are overly expensive meaning you either buy them or play for 20-30 hours for one cheap merc and about 50-60 hours for the most expensive ones
-Guns barely do any damage (not even joking, you need at least 10 body shots with an ak to kill someone), and knifes do twice the damage for some reason

Now, here's the thing, this isn't a bad game at all.. It's genuinely a decent game, doesn't feel p2w.. But you'll need to spend money in order to enjoy the game in the long run.

But i can't forgive an fps that has invisible mercs with melee weapons that do more damage than a gun for some odd reason.. Like i said, skill is very important aspect in a fps and this game lacks that in a big way.

If you wanna compare this game, compare it to TF2, but TF2 is way better anyway.. This game already only has at the most 10k active players and is a f2p on steam.. I hope im wrong, but i don't see a big future for this game unless some big changes are made.

(And to clarify, i know its a team based fps, i played a lot of TF2 and Battlefield, but my point stands)

reviewText:
I mean its pretty much TF2.
The Sniper has an SMG, the black guy throws bombs,

and you open overpriced boxes one at a time to get something that 1/10 times is useful.

Heres some real criticism for you:

Your earn about 150-200 credits a game whether you win or loose. Seems like an ok amount at first. But wait, to get new loadouts, you need to open up boxes that cost 1,000 credits, and the boxes equate to CSGO or TF2 crates of you getting 1/10 chance to get something you may like. Oh, but wait. You can trade up crap loadouts you get to get the next tier of loadout. Oh, and when you trade up you dont choose the next level loadout you get so you may or may not get something you like.

Do you want to try a new merc? There are a bunch to choose from with there own special things about them. And you can play them all right out of the gate! Right? Riiight? WRONG. Unless you pay 20$ (way to much for what the game is in my opinion) you need to buy them with real money or credits. Oh but wait! Do you love weekly free rotations? I know I don't! Well, its there, and you can play as 2 new mercs a week! Wow! What a great system! Alright, fine. You want me to unlock new mercs by playing? Fine, lets see how many credits it will cost me. 30,000 to 50,000 credits. How many credits do you get per game? About 150 to 200. Oh but there are daily missions you can do to get bonus credits! Lets take an example here: (Real in game excerpt)

Objective Monkey - Earn 10,780 Game Mode XP

How much is that really? Well you get about 100 XP every time you do something in a match.
Do the math.

Its a shame because the gun-play is really solid here. There is a cool system of secondary objectives where if the offending team does something it may give them a flank or new option to help with the main objective in game.

But I will never get used to Mobile Free-to-Play system in games that I play in my home on my computer.

I will give it a thumbs up because I love the gunplay so much, but hopefully this system of credits and paying really money to play as more mercs and get better gear goes away when the game gets its full release.

TL-DR:
-The gameplay is awesome. Gunplay feels fast paced and solid.
-Weekly rotation to play as different mercs without paying real cash is annoying since grinding enough credits to buy them is a real drag and takes forever.
-Annoying FTP mechanics to get gear thats half decent.
-More mercs being made, Nexon expects you to pay for them before they balance it.
-Anti Cheat is extremely flawed, Nexon also has access to your RAM cache while the game is installed.

EDIT: With more mercs on the way, its becoming more and more apparent that the devs expect you to pay for the class now, and balance them later. Yes some new classes perfectly counter each other, but in order for you to play as that counter you have to pay money or credits. Think of it as an Engie build a sentry in a really good spot in TF2 and you need a spy to sap it. Well the thing is you need to pay 10 dollars or 50,000 credits in order to pick the spy class. Or an Engie getting harrased by Spys, and the only way to play pyro to counter them is buy paying cash or credits. Its stupid.

Oh and its hacker central. Also the games anti cheat" has access to you RAM cache while you have the game installed. This sh*t is illegal in the EU and I dont really feel comfortable with Nexon having that kind of access on my system.

Is it worth it?: When the day comes that you can play as all classes for free I can reccomend this game. But untill that day
date: I hope you enjoy spending cash or getting ♥♥♥♥♥ by Naders and Phantoms.\nAlso
recommended: wait untill they get there anti cheat sorted out

reviewText:
One of the best multi-player FPS games I've played in a long time, a refreshing update from my CS:Source days.

Points to note:

The game is not Pay To Win. All content can be purchased with in game currency, both loadouts and mercenaries. Merc loadouts take very little time to upgrade to the top power level, the costly high-tier loadouts are purely cosmetic.
The game is objective-based. You do not win by getting the best kill/death ratio, and definitely not by picking a team full of snipers.
There are 3 main types of character: Damage, Objective Specialist, and Medic. There are several different mercs in each catagory with different abilities around their theme.
The damage per shot in relatively low compared to the likes of CounterStrike so don't expect one shot KOs with the general weaponry. However since each merc has different health levels experiences may vary.
Each map is built over two or three stages with objective completion required to progress, one team attacks while the other defends.
Overall the game is fun, fast-paced, and diverse for an FPS.

It features 3 main game modes:
Objective: Attack or Defend the objectives on a standard map (2-3 objectives).
Stopwatch: Attack AND defend the objectives on the same map, in turn, aiming to complete the map faster than the opposing team.
Execution: Counterstrike-style single objective no respawn multi-round games, taking turns to attack/defend and either complete the objective or wipe the enemy team. Aim to win more rounds than the enemy overall.

That should more or less cover the basics. It's definitely worth giving the game a shot.

Oh and I highly recommend waiting on a spot in a Max-Level 5 server while you're learning the game. It's no fun getting your ♥♥♥ handed to you while you don't know what's going on, it'll only put you off. There's actually no shame in being a noobie.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is a great team based shooter with a compelling focus on objective work.
With constant additions and updates it has been a very enjoyable experience so far.
Put simply, Brink and Team Fortress 2 combined.

PRO
- Each class is unique and has their own skills and personality
- Levels are interestingly desgined and look great
- The guns feel nice
- Things are unlockable through in-game credits
- Employs team balancing
- Objectives feel fair and not always giving one side the advantage
- This game is NOT Pay2Win. It is possible to buy characters that aren't unlocked through grinding but they are on a rotation to be unlocked for a certain amount of time so everyone gets to use them at some point.
- With each new rotation the game changes dramatically. I.e. with the addition of Stoker more people throw molotovs, with the addition of Redeye more people use smoke.

NEUTRAL
- Auto join and switching teams is a little broken but nothing gamebreaking
- Cases and Loadout cards feel lacking

CON
- Overpriced packs as DLC (All three would cost £40.57)
- No customisation at all

With basically no cons at all, I can safely say this game is great and I have enjoyed playing on ts with a friend, discussing our gameplans as we attack or defend.

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is a great team based shooter with a compelling focus on objective work.
With constant additions and updates it has been a very enjoyable experience so far.
Put simply, Brink and Team Fortress 2 combined.

PRO
- Each class is unique and has their own skills and personality
- Levels are interestingly desgined and look great
- The guns feel nice
- Things are unlockable through in-game credits
- Employs team balancing
- Objectives feel fair and not always giving one side the advantage
- This game is NOT Pay2Win. It is possible to buy characters that aren't unlocked through grinding but they are on a rotation to be unlocked for a certain amount of time so everyone gets to use them at some point.
- With each new rotation the game changes dramatically. I.e. with the addition of Stoker more people throw molotovs, with the addition of Redeye more people use smoke.

NEUTRAL
- Auto join and switching teams is a little broken but nothing gamebreaking
- Cases and Loadout cards feel lacking

CON
- Overpriced packs as DLC (All three would cost £40.57)
- No customisation at all

With basically no cons at all, I can safely say this game is great and I have enjoyed playing on ts with a friend, discussing our gameplans as we attack or defend.
This is how a team based shooter should be.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of the best multi-player FPS games I've played in a long time, a refreshing update from my CS:Source days.

Points to note:

The game is not Pay To Win. All content can be purchased with in game currency, both loadouts and mercenaries. Merc loadouts take very little time to upgrade to the top power level, the costly high-tier loadouts are purely cosmetic.
The game is objective-based. You do not win by getting the best kill/death ratio, and definitely not by picking a team full of snipers.
There are 3 main types of character: Damage, Objective Specialist, and Medic. There are several different mercs in each catagory with different abilities around their theme.
The damage per shot in relatively low compared to the likes of CounterStrike so don't expect one shot KOs with the general weaponry. However since each merc has different health levels experiences may vary.
Each map is built over two or three stages with objective completion required to progress, one team attacks while the other defends.
Overall the game is fun, fast-paced, and diverse for an FPS.

It features 3 main game modes:
Objective: Attack or Defend the objectives on a standard map (2-3 objectives).
Stopwatch: Attack AND defend the objectives on the same map, in turn, aiming to complete the map faster than the opposing team.
Execution: Counterstrike-style single objective no respawn multi-round games, taking turns to attack/defend and either complete the objective or wipe the enemy team. Aim to win more rounds than the enemy overall.

That should more or less cover the basics. It's definitely worth giving the game a shot.

Oh and I highly recommend waiting on a spot in a Max-Level 5 server while you're learning the game. It's no fun getting your ♥♥♥ handed to you while you don't know what's going on, it'll only put you off. There's actually no shame in being a noobie.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is an amazing little game that has the same issues that any beta has (a bit of lag here and there, some optimization tweaks, not as much content as a polished product, and some balance tweaks). But it has solid gunplay, fun movement mechanics, nice class design, and solid writing. All the ingame dialogue is very funny and reasonably well voiced.

It isn't p2w, either. People may claim it is, but people are dumb. You pay to skip the grind. The grind isn't even that painful. Games like Warframe or most any moba can only bow their head in shame. A merc costs 50k credits, and I can earn 15k in a day pretty easily thanks to the revamped mission system. Basicaly; do the missions (play using this merc/play this game type/perform this role), and you'll get credits. Missions refresh every 3 hours, and any completed missions will be replaced with new ones.

For a beta, it's a very solid product. And it has amazing potential. It's been a long time since I was this pumped for an FPS.

reviewText:
This game is a hard core FPS that requires very good aim (tracking) and teamwork. It has a high learning curve, so be prepared to put in some time. After a while though you will find yourself hooked to its fast movement, rewarding aiming and necessary teamwork. Try it and don't give up on it after a few hours. I am sure you'll love it! There is already a competitive scene with active cups and matches and this game is still in closed beta, sais enough doesnt it?

Don't let nexon put you off: splash damage is in complete controll of the monetization so don't expect any form of rental etc. What you get either with credits or money is yours forever: f o r e v e r. Also everything is unlockable with ingame credits earned by playing. So this game is not pay2win eventhough nexon is involved. They just provide servers and advertising. Currently the monetization needs some work mainly due to a broken card system, but hey its a beta.

Card system? Yes is like a moba FPS. There are no classes in this game but just mercs with their own abilities. You recieve special loadout cards with augments and skins that lightly alter the way the character plays. Think more attacker or support oriented, a different gun etc. This is all quite balanced. The main problem atm is that skins are connected to load outs, which is likely to change in the future.

It is awesome. I highly recommend playing this game if you are into a classic aim and teamplay oriented shooter with a bright graphic style, smooth and fast movement and already an awesome community.

About the bad reviews: you will see those are players who have played the game just for a couple of hours, sometimes not even 1 hour. This is to be expected as the gameplay is realy demanding a high level of skill and teamplay. This high learning curve can make it frustrating in the beginning, hence the bad reviews.

Some recomended movies:
movement: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-LJUmnLDpDw
trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jKDWMMSMhdI

reviewText:
Teamwork makes the dream work! A fantastic game all around. WARNING - Not for a lone wolf style player. You would be better suited to CoD or Battlefield.

The community is encouraging and helpful so far, and I don't see a lot of room for toxicity beyond a player who chooses to not work towards the common objectives.

EDITED FOR OPEN BETA:

Definitely menu lag with the large number of players online. You can still do what you need to do in the barracks and game browser though.

Some minor bugs while in game that generally don't affect gameplay. Primarily visual bugs.

Competitive has really taken off. I would suggest checking out the VODs on twitch.tv/dirtycups and watching some tournaments in action if you are interested!

Also, be sure to check out the forums as there is a LOT to learn about this game. I am still learning things 150+ hours in.

reviewText: DirtyBomb - Open Beta: FPS game based on using strong teamwork to attack or defend objectives. If you liked Brink you will be right at home with DB as it is similar and made by the same company, SplashDammage. Some say it is also like TF2 mixed with CS:GO but either way, it is a great game. It IS in Beta so there are bugs and some mercs need to be balanced a little better but overal the devs have done a great job of keeping things fare. As for P2W factor, it is non-existant. There is absolutly no way you can say that this game is P2W. It is a true F2P game. This game is fun to solo on the public servers and even better when you can grab some friends and join a competitive match and put your skills to the test. Over all a very well done game for being in beta. I look forward to the future of DB as I belive it will be a bright one. I give it a rating of 9/10 due to bugs and optimization but I am going easy because DB is in Beta. If DB was a full release the rating would be lower. Definitly a good game and I highly recomend you download it and try it out for yourself. Good luck and have fun guys.

reviewText:
You're a lvl 7 Proxy
Last objective on underground
They have a team full of Rhinos
10 seconds left until the bomb explodes
You feel the courage to step on that sight, be the hero you spent money on the game to be.
You start defusing, BUT WAIT, your own proxy mine.. it is right under your feet
You panic! You shoot it out of fear that someone might blow it up on you...Wait.

In all seriousness, try the game, its free, if ya dont like it, delete it.
If you find you enjoy it, spend all your money you got from your mum for christmas on it, level up and 'Pwn n00ps'
Game is fast paced so if you aren't into that, this game probably isn't for you.
If you like games that you like playing for fun with friends, give it a try :D

reviewText:
Nice F2P shooter which is very doable without ever spending any real money on it. Unfortunately it suffers from quite some imbalances, but this is to be expected in a beta stage (Example: Hagar's grenade launcher one shots everything and everyone).The mechanics are fast-paced and anyone with a knack for running and gunning will appreciate these. However (and this is personal experience) player base seems to be full of *ahem* ♥♥♥♥♥, who join low level servers at a high level just to ♥♥♥♥ on players.

7/10

+ Great gameplay
+ Not Pay 2 win
+ Class variety

- Maps are a little bland
- Player community
- Map/weapon imbalances

Right now I do not recommend this game, despite it's good gameplay, due to the aforementioned issues. However, this may change as the game progresses through it's open beta stage and becomes more balanced and tweaked.

reviewText:
While I enjoy the general concept of the game it needs a LOT more work to make it worthwhile to keep playing it, I feel right now you are better off playing something else until they improve on the game.
What I liked:
- gunplay is pretty nice, enjoying it a lot
- decent weapon diversity
- some voices are pretty well done
- escort missions are fun
What was annoying:
- after running the game for more than 30 minutes, I can't close it normally, have to use task manager
- there's little variety in objective missions, and few maps, gets old really fast
- the balancing of classes and loadouts needs a lot of work
- competitive mode seems completely broken, 2 times got kicked back to menu when loading its map, 3 times crashed to desktop, and when it worked  its full of cheaters
- the game really needs better anti-cheat and some active moderation on banning cheaters, Xigncode is untrustworthy garbage
- the ammo support classes abilities feel way too similiar, needs more diveristy
- takes too long to get credits for unlocks
- loadout cases give random cards, which would be fine, if the 3 perk louadouts werent so expensive, the whole random card thing feels really out of place, would be better if it was only skins instead
- 50k credits for most characters feels too much, 30k would be more reasonable
- I feel the mission system ruins the actual gameplay, most of the time the public matches are completly unbalanced team wise, and I have yet to see successful team scramble vote go through. Feels like majority of the people only plays to farm the credits and do missions, not to have a fun close match, which in the long run is completely pointless.
- you can't change weapon loadout for the character you picked during the game, which is rather odd, makes it rather pointless to get more than one good card, unless you feel like experimenting
- no auto-balance on public server, scramble votes never go through, leads to very very rare actual close games. Spawn camping/getting spawn camped gets old really fast, and it's what happens majority of the games. In the time I played I had maybe 4 or 5 close games. Most of the time one team has combined score of almost 80k while other barely gets to 2k, just to show the disparity.

Finding myself playing less and less after the initial new game hype"
recommended: the further I get the less interested I am in logging in again. Game has potential
hoursPlayed: hopefully they can sort it out

reviewText:
A seemingly big issue with DB is that with the persistent bugs, SD has been unable to keep people actually playing this game so even though you as a player are constantly gaining levels your teammates are almost always in the 7 to 15 range which seems to be the drop off point for most people.  Creating actual new content that isn't cosmetic seems to be the biggest hurdle for Splash Damage at this point because even though they have created this amazing atmophere for the game, the events and loadouts are absolutely crippled by poorly communicated RNG elements which seems to be EVERYONES biggest gripe with this game, new or old.  Unless you like trinkets that you add to your gun that only you can see, then you're out of luck because theres literally nothing else to buy that is worth your money which is kinda silly once you realize this game is soley dependant of monetization and the lack thereof is sealing the games fate.

Something that has always personally bothered me about the developement of DirtyBomb is that they over the past year staggered the release of content that was seen in the closed beta only to be released in a untouched state and then completely redone and nerfed in the the preceeding patch/hotfix.  So once the broken characters have sat on the back burner for a couple months the devs respond by making tweaks that literally nobody has asked for (EMP Phantom, seriously???) and nerfing characters that belong to the in-game meta, because ♥♥♥♥, why not? The competitive scene is deader than nu-metal.  Instead of making broken mercs play well, they nerf nicely working characters to sit more in line with the broken ones and the same thing goes for card augments.  Most changes we have seen this year to the game have been focused entirely on those casual low level players that quit the game @ level 15 which doesn't  seem to paint a positive future for DB at all.

I'm writing this review just a few days after the game hits its 1 year anniversary into open beta and frankly the game is not in a good place.   Ranked is currently disabled due to a bug in SD's flagship gamemode Stopwatch" causing teams to draw even though there was a clear winner.  Public matches are a unbalanced mess and are usually stomps/obliterations. The game will often stack all the high levels against the low levels for seemingly no reason. The amount of crazy crap going on in game now is amplified
date: and down right unfun if you're facing  the likes of Thunder
hoursPlayed: Phantom  or the snipers (or any combination of these.)  SD has always expressed the importance of the speed factor in DirtyBomb
voteText:
but characters like Thunder and Phantom directly go against that philosophy.  Don't like being flashed and your entire screen going white every 16 seconds?  Don't like being killed by some dude that is legit invisible? Well Dirty Bomb is def not the game for you


Execution mode is an absolute joke. If SD wants to think of when things started to go downhill
helpfulPercent: its with the release of this game mode that nearly everyone hates.  Execution is nothing more than a glorified deathmatch with a bomb shoehorned in. It is a complete waste of developmenet resources. Go into a match of Execution and 2/3rds of the people there will tell you they're only there to complete their dailies. On paper 'Execution' doesn't work
votesHelpful:
in practice 'Execution" doesn't work.  The individual abilities and mercs strengths & weaknesses simply do not work in this gamemode.

Incredibly sluggish user interface that eats up an immense amount of CPU

Nexon Game Security:  The 'anti-cheat' kicks more legitimate players than it does ones that are actually cheating. I'm not going to blame SD on this one because I'm sure they are contractually obligated to use Nexon's anti cheat but this thing is a heaping pile of garbage.  During the ReV event I had to restart my computer before playing DB everytime or I'd get kicked for a game security violation in my first match.  Think of how many legitimate players DB has turned away because they couldn't stop getting kicked for not actually cheating?  The last dev stream I watched even they got kicked for Game Security Violation on their own game!  Oh and if NGS crashes
votesTotal:
so will your game

Events crippled by miscommunicated RNG elements

See-Saw effect of balancing: Changes are made to certain mercs/augments/cards with seemingly no consideration as to how they will affect other characters in the game. For example; Fletcher is completely check-mated by phantom in the current build. There isn't a single character in the game that is as countered as Fletcher is by Phantom which means there is very little reason to play Fletch (my favourite merc) over Bush which is currently superior in every single way.  The same thing goes for guns/augments. Certain guns/augments will be in such a bad state for such a long time that you trade out all your cards featuing the weapons/augments only for them to eventually add some balance months down the line but its too late because you've already traded.

Gen 2 cards:  There are still mostly only 3/9 usuable cards for any given merc

Devaluing limited edition items:   With the release of gen2 cards
votesFunny: a large percentage of Gen1 (event/cobalt/gold) cards are now worth pennies.  "Coalsplitter" trinket
commentsCount: a free trinket that is the combination of two LIMITED EDITION (one cost $5) items given away for free? Seriously?\n\nRanked has never recovered from the hacker spree of Summer 2015 and no matter what SD does to revitalize it
column16: it hasn't worked yet.\n\n"Open Beta" :  You can't just excuse the stuff I've mentioned above by stating "The game is still in beta!"  --  it really isn't
column17: Name one other beta game that has $40 RNG DLC (cards) and has been around as long as DB. The store functions better than any other aspect of the game and in my opinion as soon as you start monetizing your game
column18: you're no longer in beta\nDirty Bomb is my favourite game

reviewText:
Now i'm an avid FPS player, played RTCW/Wolfenstein: Enemy territory/Rise of the Triad but really don't see the resemblance that much other then a few gameplay mechanics... Still it's nice gameplay and it's improved a lot since early days.

Fast TTK (Time to kill)
Obj-driven gameplay
class-based teamwork
Strafing/Trick-walljumping due to Quake-Engine
movement not impeded even whilst under fire
hipfire promoted
need to gib kills.
Overall very solid (been testing since alpha) and finally one that stands out!

I even managed to hit 60fps stable with i5 processor and nvidia 720M series

It's set to go completely F2P but is at the moment still in Closed Beta, if you do decide to play please leave some viable feedback or add me and come play with me <3

Mercs can be bought as early access" form at the moment. (and unlocked through gameplay)

reviewText: There seems to be a misunderstanding on what loadout cards are and whether they're pay2win or not. Loadouts go from led(1 perk)>iron(2 perks)>bronze(3 perks)>silver(3 perks)>gold(3 perks)>cobalt(3 perks). ALL loadouts have random perks and guns. After bronze cards, its purely cosmetic. Bronze cards are very easy to make, often taking only a day to make. SILVER GOLD AND COBALT are cosmetic ONLY, the point is to take a risk and make a high tier card that has good stats/weapons. You can only pay for cosmetics. The guns and stats you DO get from it are equal to bronze cards that anyone can easily make.

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is splash damage's successor to their hit FPS Brink. And we all know how much I ♥♥♥♥ing love Brink.
Brink was the masterpiece of all FPS', surpassing popular FPS games such as Halo, Counter Strike, Call of Duty, and Battlefield all in one go. Repetitive objective, bullet sponge player characters, parkour, and stupidly good AI TRULY set this masterpiece a part from the shovelware FPS's of its era. In addition, its story WAS the multiplayer, so we could all get engaged with the cardboard characters of the story, and the plot that noone cares about. Truly a goldmine of gaming.

Now can Splash Damage follow up with another good game, and free us from the mountain of ♥♥♥♥ FPS's such as Battlefield Hardline, Call of Duty Advanced Warfare, and Titanfall?

Short Answer? No. If thats all you came for, then please leave as I go and do an IN-DEPTH analysis of everything about this game.

Story:
This game follows in Brink’s fabulous footsteps. Do you have a ♥♥♥♥ing clue whats going on? No. Its in London I guess. Two factions are duking it out all throughout London, blowing up buildings with EMP’s somehow, Capturing datacores by driving trains through buildings, and many more crazy missions. For what you may ask?
I HAVE NO ♥♥♥♥ING IDEA, AND NEITHER WILL YOU.
In addition, these two factions use clone technology rather excessively, as you have a choice of a handful of mercs, and everyone who plays them looks the exact ♥♥♥♥ing same. We have no idea why these few were chosen to be heavily cloned, so it leaves much for the player to decide with this story. I love stories that I HAVE to come up with to make sense of things. In this aspect, Dirty Bomb gets it right. Vague storylines are the way to go.

Graphics:
This game follows Brink’s classic art style, except this time I’m getting constantly good frames, which sucks. I much rather my graphics lag all to ♥♥♥♥. Now this may be my elite rig doing all the work with its 256KB of RAM, and its Appian J Pro graphics card, but I think they honestly tried to improve the graphics to run smoothly, which really takes away from the atmosphere of the Brink series. So for this reason, I’m going to list graphics as a con. The low framerates really made the Brink environment more believable.

Gameplay:
Now for the important bit. The gameplay. As we all know, the gameplay from this game’s predecessor, Brink, was the very peak of the gaming experience not too long ago. It brought small, repetitive map design, incredibly simple objectives, parkour, and many other things.
The first on Splash’s chopping block was the parkour. You can no longer wall run, and only wall jump, making Parkour that much harder to pull off.  This makes the very FEW parkour obstacles harder to pull off, and as we all know, parkour is VERY easy to pull off in real life. This makes this game incredibly unrealistic. Its limited parkour is a con for this game.

Now for the map design. The map design is pretty non-repetitive, making this game stupidly hard, as I know have to remember all these hot spots and map configurations, where I could simply remember one map and do just fine in Brink. Having the player juggle all these maps together is artificial difficulty, and for that reason, the map design is a con.

There are about 10-ish classes right now, as opposed to Brink’s four. However Brink had four VERY unique classes, where this game has some classes that have similar if not the same abilities and weapons. Why have more classes if you are not going to take the time to make them all unique?

Now I wanna go more into this, but thinking of all its features that Brink did so well that were destroyed by this game makes me want to cringe. So I’ll move on.

Music:
This game has music?

As you can see, Splash Damage tries to improve a flawless game, and instead only creates flaws that diminish Brink's great story and atmosphere. Splash Damage could have handed me a literal copy of brink and wrote a 2 beside Brink" on the cover with permanent marker
date: and I would have much rather bought that instead. This game's price tag is ♥♥♥♥ing ridiculous for what this game is."

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb I initially enjoyed until the grind reared it's ugly head almost right off the bat. I mean, it has a great movement system and nice classes that would have been so cool in a different game with bigger maps and more open ended battle than a bunch of corners in which campers utilize to avoid using said movement system and for said classes to place proximity mines behind.

On a good game you will get 200-500 credits per 15 or so minute match, and most classes require 30k to 50k, and even then their good loadouts cost 17k or so a pop. I'm not playing this game that long with the low amount of maps on offer here and the unbalanced gameplay. You will seldom have a game where one team doesn't steamroll the other one. There's a loadout crafting feature in place to make the grind feel like less of a grind, but cases seem to only come like once in a blue moon, almost always land on loadouts for classes you don't have yet, and you need 3 of them to make a new loadout for a class you DO have.

It also, without fail, will always seem to cocktease you with a super rare loadout, but then pick the one directly next to it. 9/10 times there was a rare loadout right next to the one RNG picks from the case. To the point where I'm convinced that's an intentional ♥♥♥♥ you".

It feels like every game is won by who can camp the best and in the largest numbers within the tightest spaces. I initially started doing what the game seemed like what it was designed for
date: which is walljumping and essentially playing it like battlefield 2 meets quake 3
recommended: running around and fragging people left and right but then I tried playing it like a camper would in call of duty just to see if the problem was with my own skill and I saw my KD/R increase by a disgusting margin.\n\nI would not recommend this game to anyone except the CoD crowd."

reviewText:
I like it, despite it MASSIVE flaws.

Pros:
Characters are Unique
Fun to play
Controls are responsive

Cons:
Client Side everything, which has super huge netcoding issues, if you play the Battlefield Series, you understand the problems this gets. For those of you that don't, you will have very big issues when playing with people who have severe latency differences.

Cheats Everywhere, the game has no reliable anti-cheat system, and the one it does have is laughable. Even in the competative scene, which would be called ranked for most other games, cheaters are everywhere. So it's a joke to take it seriously at this time.

Completely imbalanced and toxic community. Getting Spawn Killed, prepare to be told to git gud, some player wants to go around and talk about how much of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ they are, kicking them basically requires the entire team to vote. There is no Base ♥♥♥♥ Protocol, in lay mans terms a part of the game that prevents people from sieging the spawn point to prevent the enemies from even participating in the game. This happens all the time, players will enter the spawn when no one is there and sit back and kill you after you spawn.

No balancing system, when you join a match you are able to decide what side you want to be on Attacker or Defender, however the game does not balance players in the match so you could have 8v2 and the game will do nothing to balance until the match is over. Additionally the game attempts no balance based on skill, so a team of level 8+ could fight a team of level 1's and 2's and the game does nothing to balance this out. Which is very hostile to new players.

This game says it is in Open Beta, but receives microtransactions, which means they are confident enough their game is able to make money. So to me that game is fully released, as such it should be held to the same standards as other released games.

In terms of fun it can be 10/10 or it could be 1/10 it depends solely on the random people you get placed with and against.

In terms of balance 1/10 it has no real way to stop cheaters, botters, hackers at all. So if you get one on the enemie team, well your ♥♥♥♥ out of luck, either leave the server or die over and over. But this happens oftern so be prepared to shift servers 3-4 times before you get one that isn't bad.

In player base, out of the hundred of people I played with and against, most stayed quiet, a few dozen decided to be openly hostile and a few were nice.

Do I recommend this game, no, I don't it's looking like a cash grab at the moment as it has some serious problems with how it is managed. If those get fixed, sure I'll recommend it, otherwise, stay away unless you enjoy torture.

reviewText:
I never played any of the games people compare Dirty Bomb to, but I played in the prior closed beta and really enjoyed the game. My comparison is a Team Fortress 2 game but with military characters.

Gameplay is fast paced while staying team based. You dont die instantly (which I hate in most games), and gives you time to rethink any given situations most times, or even run across a guarded path.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone. I play basically solo 100% of the time, but if you can get some of your buddies with you, I would expect the fun factor to sky rocket.

reviewText:
Oh boy here we go.
This game is great.

Almost everything can be bought with in-game currency, or through random drop cases. 100 hours in, I've gotten 2 silvers, a gold, and a cobalt; as well as bought 3 different mercs. This was done just by playing, so the whole paying cash for the rare cases/mercs thing isn't worth it really.

In-game currency is easily obtainable, characters are somewhat balanced, and team play is really good, since everyone's spawned in waves. Every team needs an ammo guy, a healer, and objective specialist to be successful, and I really like that. One person can't make or break a team, you always need to work together.

The hacking problem aside, this game is a ton of fun for me. Only thing I wish could be implemented would be trading loadout cards and reverse crafting (e.g. 1 gold = 3 random silvers)

Would recommend.

reviewText:
A good start, but needs improvement.  I'll start with what the game does well, and then move on to what needs work.

The Good:

This game is *FAST*.  I'm sick of slow shooters and Dirty Bomb just feels great.  Movement speed is nice, damage is high but not CSGO / CoD high, there's wall jumping (albeit not extremely useful)

This game's gunplay is right on point.  Meaty explosions, nice powerful sounding weapons... the feedback is excellent.  Splash Damage, as usual, delivers strong shooty bits.

The netcode is good.  Anything below 120 feels very playable without extremely annoying hitbox problems.  I've played many FPS's that were ruined in part by poor netcode.  This isn't one of them.

This game is updated frequently and developers communicate frequently with the playerbase.  Problems aside, they atleast listen and update us frequently on changes.

Stuff that needs work:

Firstly, you don't get all the mercs in one go.  You can't even pay for a total merc unlock in any reasonable $ amount.  Mercs are 30k to 50k, and be prepared to grind weeks out just to get a single merc unless you can play several hours every day.  The prices need a SERIOUS adjustment.  Cutting credit costs in half would do wonders.

Next, the microtransactions are a waste.  Credit boosters do not mathematically make any sense.  30k mercs cost $7, while 50k mercs cost $10.  The packages you can buy also are poorly thought out, as if you already have mercs in any of the packages you actually lose out on value.  Example:  the starter pack has Vasilli and Sawbonez in it.  I have already unlocked both of these mercs, so if I buy the starter pack, I lose out on a hefty amount of value.  At this point, I have atleast one merc in every single bundle - basically, I lose out no matter what bundle I'd like which ensures that there's no way I'll pay for it.  You can also buy elite cases with real money which is a waste because they are overpriced and there's no garauntee you'll even get something worthwhile.

NEEDS MORE MAPS!

Finally, due to this game's freegame nature - cheating is absolutely rampant.  Check the Steam forums / nexon forums to see why.  Since this isn't a paid game, cheaters do not worry about being banned as they just re-register a new account.  The game's anticheat is XIGN which is infamous at slow updates.  There is also no way of reporting many cheaters who use unknown characters.

In it's present state, I'll give it a 6/10.  I'll address this later as more classes, balance, and maps are added.  But, as it is in Beta and is Free-To-Play, I recommend it for all you FPS fans.

reviewText: The game is a team based game. Which means that you need your teammates to help you play the objs and hold down an area. You are more likely to win if you are denfending in the match. This being said you have to confrim your kills so he doesn't get back up and kill you.

reviewText:
Dirty Bomb is a class-based arena (style) shooter.
In Dirty Bomb one team must either destroy an objective, repair an objective, or move an objective from point A to B; where the other team will try to stop it.

All Mercs (characters) have different types of equipment: some can heal, drop ammo packs, call in airstrikes, etc.
Loadouts are cards, you receive cards from either getting them dropped at the end of a game, or buying them for 1,000 ingame credits (about 2 matches worth of credits).
Cards have different rarities, the rarer, the more perks you have.
Higher rarity also changes the cosmetics of your character, ie: different camo on clothing and weapons.

Cards can be traded up for several cards of the same rarity plus a small amount of credits.
Each character has 3 different primary and secondary and knives which you might get.
Each character has different roles because of their weapons and equipment, and a different card (loadout) may change your playstyle because of the weapons or perks, etc.

There are 2 mercs which are permanently unlocked, and some mercs you can play as or a limited time because of free-rotation, which cycles mercs every few weeks. You can permanently unlock Mercs with either ingame credits, or cash.
This certainly isn't pay2win, because if you buy a merc, other people may be able to use it in a few weeks.
It only takes about 6-10 hours of playtime to be able to afford a merc with ingame cash anyway.

You can aim down sights, but it is not reccomended as there is nearly no (extreme) recoil, and it slows you down.
Time to kill in this game is considerably long if you go for body shots, which is why headshots are always reccommended, as it's only 2-3 shots with an AR.

Pros and Cons.

Pros:
-Attractive visuals
-F2P, but buying things with cash does not give an unfair advantage
-Accessible game with a high skill ceiling, easy to learn but hard to master
-Free rotation mixes up gameplay
-The game has under level 5" servers for people new to the game
-You're able to walljump twice and keep momentum
date:
making awesome trick jumps and skill based movement possible
-Gun play is great
-Hitboxes seem fine

Negatives:
-Some maps and classes need tweaking
recommended:
ie: longer cooldown for airstrikes
-Lack of gamemodes and maps
-The game requires a lot of communication and team work for your team to be successful.
"

reviewText: This game has solid shooter mechanics, not pay to win.  I usually have a normal squad of men that I use depending on who is available for the week. All in all, I have a ton of fun playing.

reviewText:
A team based game in which mercenaries of varying skills and abilities battle it out to complete or defend objectives. Each character has their own kooky personality, traits, and accents, differentiating each other effectively. And I can’t think of a good Segway, so I’m just calling it out: The developers, Splash Damage, once worked on another title with similar gameplay. You may have heard of it, it was called Brink. Now Brink was a little bit of a broken, messy disaster when it first came out. It didn’t help itself by immediately calling itself a rival to Team Fortress 2, which went as well as the new weedy kid at school challenging the biggest guy in the playground to a fight, in a misguided attempt to assert his dominance. Splash Damage seem to have learned from their past mistakes and have worked to make Dirty Bomb a pretty fun game.

As stated before, Dirty Bomb splits players up into two teams. One team defends the objectives, the other team has to attack the objectives. These can range from blowing up a generator to blowing up a wall, blowing up a set of controls, or blowing up an entire building. In fact, there isn’t much variety there. Whether it’s the first, second or sometimes third objective, players will be detonating something. The most fun objective to attack and defend are the EV trucks. Attackers must escort it by walking alongside or mounting the turret while defenders need to disable it. Once it’s disabled, the defenders need to keep it disabled while attackers have to repair it. It’s strangely satisfying to call in a tactical nuke to blow the repairers away, especially with the fact that they get a warning before the explosion.


I surely would recommend this game to anyone. 9/10

reviewText:
This is your unusual triple A hardcore fast-paced asymmetric objective based team shooter, with a lot of roles to dive into and learn. It rewards teamwork, communication, good aim, movement, persistence, awareness and map- and merc knowledge. If you are into that stuff, you will spend hundreds of hours on it. The mechanics and mercs are very balanced, yet refreshingly asymmetric. Focus from the developers is on competition and good and diverse gameplay, all free to play (via rotation,) with no microtransactions and no P2W, as the most versatile mercs are the cheapest and are included in the Starter Pack, or easily grinded. Within your first hour of play, you will permanently have unlocked three mercs, two of the most allrounded support mercs and a merc of your choosing. Obviously the grind picks up a bit from there.The monetization model follows that of HOTS.
The learning curve is like the game of chess: easy to pick up, hard to learn and impossible to master. This does not mean it's not a game for casuals though, it is, just of a more mature audience or one that enjoys complexity.
System requirements are low: most stationary personal computers from the past four years with a dedicated graphics card will be able to run it decently with medium to low graphics, yet it still looks great! Besides a dedicated graphics card (similar to Nvidia GTX260, or better) I'd recommend at least a dual-core processor. This is on the low end though, and minimum specs are expected to change over time.

FYI there will be no more account wipes, so everything you unlock, is yours to keep.

Warning: this is not a game for COD-kiddies crying hacks! Campers won't find much enjoyment either.

reviewText:
Introduction:
I dont normally do reviews (because I suck at them) , but I just had to do one for this title. I first heard of Dirty Bomb from the Youtuber MrMuselk.

My overall description:
Dirty Bomb is one of the most refreashing titles I have played in ages, it breathes new life into the co-opretive team based genre of shooters (some examples of these: Team Fortress 2, Counter-Strike Series). The pure adreneline constantly coming from this game is overwhelming at points, every charachter moves at a very fast speed in this game, so reaction time is required. The games main objectives for every map made up to this point is basically a form of the Attack/Defense mode from TF2, mixed with the stress of the bomb defusal mode in the Counter-Strike series. This mix of gamemodes works extremely well, and I have yet to find a dull moment in this game because of this mix.

Pros:
ITS FREE, Really fair and easy to progress F2P model, in the sense that you cannot purchase in game currency with real money, ITS FREE, runs pretty well on most decent rigs, ITS FREE. Also, its still in beta, so the game can only improve from here on out, and its already one of my favorite MMO's in a long time.

Cons:
Some of the Brink devs had a role in this, so take that as you wish. Sometimes finding a US East server can be challenging, it shouldnt affect most of you though. 2 charachters are extremely unbalanced currently, but the devs have agknowladged this, so it should be fixed soon.

Closing:
Just play it, its a fast download, and free, the only purpose of this review is to give you the first impression of it not sucking. Have fun!!!
~Lost

reviewText:
One of the more frustrating Free to play FPS out there

Crashes for no reason:

I could be playing for an hour + and then...

SURPRISE YOU GOT KICKED FROM THE GAME DUE TO A SECURITY VIOLATION or GAME HAS STOPPED WORKING

But i.. .. i was just trying to defuse the c4 :<.. at that point you know the game hates you

Business model is like most freemium games:

For those who like to gamble with their monies for loots.. this is a game you should try... You can pay for boosts/cases with real monies. Otherwise... there is no cure for the grind... you gotta put in the hours if you want the shinies

MatchMaking:

As with any matchmaking decided games, there are times where you get games that are completely uneven... and one side will completely crush the other side :<

However the game is fast paced so you only have to live through these moments for ~10 minutes or so...

Gameplay/Mechanics:

Graphics are pretty!

The wall jumping mechanics are really nice... i wish i could jump better :3

The learning curve isnt too bad either, it seems to be easy to pick up on... and skills are transferrable from other fps games..

VOIP is enabled in game, but beware of people getting frustrated and saying nonsense into the mic (they tend to blame other people for pretty much an entire team <including themselves> poor performances... or maybe the other team is just that much better...)

Good thing is that you should be able to Mute those people if you choose to.


What it needs:
Crew mechanics where you can start a small squad and join games together!
STOP CRASHING ME DURING IMPORTANT MOMENTS!

Pretty much on the fence about this review ... as you can tell
